headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the FirstEnergy Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Meghan Beringer, Director of Investor Relations. Thank yo
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the FirstEnergy Fourth Quarter Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Meghan Beringer, Director of Investor Relations. Thank you, Ms. Beringer, you may now begin.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Manny, and good morning. Welcome to FirstEnergy's Fourth Quarter earnings call. First, please be reminded that during this conference call, we will make various forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Safe Harbor provisions of the
componenttext:
Thank you, Manny, and good morning. Welcome to FirstEnergy's Fourth Quarter earnings call. First, please be reminded that during this conference call, we will make various forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Safe Harbor provisions of the United States Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that such forward-looking statements with respect to revenues, earnings, performance, strategies, prospects and other aspects of the business of FirstEnergy Corp. are based on current expectations that are subject to risks and uncertainties. A number of factors could cause actual results or outcomes to differ materially from those indicated by such.
Today, we will be referring to operating earnings, operating earnings per share, operating earnings per share by segment and adjusted EBITDA, which are all non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures are contained in the consolidated report, the updated fact book as well as on the Investor Relations information section on our website at www.firstenergycorp.com/ir.
Participating in today's call are Chuck Jones, President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Pearson, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Leila Vespoli, Executive Vice President, Market, and Chief Legal Officer; Donnie Schneider, President of FirstEnergy Solutions; Jon Taylor, Vice President, Controller and Chief Accounting Officer; Steve Staub, Vice President and Treasurer; and Irene Prezelj, Vice President, Investor Relations. 
Now, I will turn the call over to Chuck Jones.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Megan, and good morning, everyone. It's my pleasure to talk with you today. For today's call, we are deliberately keeping our prepared remarks rather brief so there will be plenty of time taking your questions at the end. Clearly, the topic many o
componenttext:
Thanks, Megan, and good morning, everyone. It's my pleasure to talk with you today. For today's call, we are deliberately keeping our prepared remarks rather brief so there will be plenty of time taking your questions at the end. Clearly, the topic many of you will be most interested in is our 2015 earnings guidance, which we made public late last evening. But before moving to that discussion, I'd like to take a moment to thank Tony Alexander for his leadership at FirstEnergy over the past decade. 
Tony guided our company through a dramatic expansion and navigated through one of the most challenging periods in the history of the utility industry. As you know, we also announced last night that Tony's last day will be April 30 and we certainly wish him well as he begins his new chapter in his life and enjoys more time with his family. Since moving into the CEO position on January 1, I've had the opportunity either meet personally or talk with many of you over the telephone. We've had some good two-way conversations over the past couple of months and I want you to know that the entire FirstEnergy team is committed to providing frank and open discussion about the challenges and opportunities we are facing as a company. That's why in light of the recent Pennsylvania rate case settlements, we decided to provide you with our earnings guidance range earlier than originally planned, so you would have a clear sense of what we are expecting this year. 
The 2015 operating earnings guidance range of $2.40 to $2.70 per share is in line with the updated drivers for our utilities business and corporate segment that we provided in November, although some Street expectations have not been adjusted to reflect that information. Looking at consensus estimates, we saw fairly widespread of about $0.50, ranging from $2.60 to over $3.10 and we understand the challenges of modeling FirstEnergy, getting all the moving pieces we have right now. 
Given the disparity between the Street consensus and our 2015 base earnings, we believe it's very critical to ground investment community on earnings sooner rather than later as we reset our utilities around the new growth strategy. 
After today, our focus shifts to customer service driven growth across the Utility segment. In that light, now that we have made our 2015 earnings guidance public, following this call, Irene and her Investor Relations team will be happy to answer your detailed questions about all the disclosures we made yesterday and today, including here in our consolidated report and in our updated fact book. 
In the future, once all the pending rate case proceedings are finalized, modeling our going forward earnings power should be far more transparent. And we hope to better articulate that for you later this year at the analyst meeting, where we expect to provide a growth target for our utilities, as well as an overall strategic update on all 3 of our business segments. 
We continue to believe the initiatives that were put in place during 2014 laid the path for our future growth and success. So let's take several minutes to review the key events of the past year. We successfully launched our Energizing the Future transmission expansion program. Under this program, we will invest billions of dollars with an eye towards serving our customers better. These investments will improve reliability, add resiliency to the bulk electric system and install enhanced physical and cyber security to ensure our assets perform as designed. 
With our multiple rate proceedings, we have also set the stage for similar investments in our regulated businesses and more timely recovery of those investments. The recent major storm events that have impacted FirstEnergy service territory have highlighted indeed for the hardening of our distribution systems.
And of course, in the wake of the polar vortex and other severe weather events last winter, we began taking a former conservative approach in our competitive business to limit risk and focus on greater stability.
We have made good progress on these efforts. Our West Virginia rate case settlement was approved by the state Public Service Commission earlier this month. And we have filed settlements in our Pennsylvania and Ohio rate proceedings that require regulatory approval. We also look forward to closure on the base rate case at JCP&L and remain hopeful that the Board of Public Utilities final decision in that proceeding will appropriately include the $580 million incurred by JCP&L for the 2012 storms. 
Once that case is finalized, we look forward to working with the BPU to make Jersey Central Power and Light a stronger company going forward. In our ATSI proceeding, we believe FERC's approval of our request to move the forward-looking rates as of January 1 signals support for transmission investments for grid reliability. As we anticipated, FERC accepted it subject to refund and also set hearing and settlement procedures and initiated an inquiry on ATSI's return on equity. We believe that more timely recovery associated with forward-looking rates is a major benefit to us, which outweighs the impact of a potentially modest ROE adjustment. This rate structure for ATSI will provide a much better correlation to our cost as we continue to implement our Energizing the Future transmission investment plan. That plan is comprised primarily of thousands of small customer focused transmission projects and equipment upgrades that can be implemented relatively quickly across our existing 24,000 miles of transmission assets. These projects are designed to enhance system reliability and resiliency for our customers while providing long-term and sustainable growth for FirstEnergy. 
I strongly believe that the right investments are those that customers value and are willing to pay for and that provide attractive returns for our investors. It's gratifying to report on a successful first year of that program. We overcame some weather-related setbacks early in the year, but by December, we successfully completed our plan of $1.4 billion in new investments, spanning more than 1,100 projects. You can see the impact of that investment when you look at our financial disclosures for the Transmission segment. 
The plan for 2015 calls for an additional $970 million investment across 430 projects, including 1,000 pieces of substation equipment and 300,000 transmission lines. By the end of this year, we expect to be well on track to meet our 4-year goal of $4.2 billion in investments through 2017. Key projects for 2015 include construction of a new substation and transmission line near Clarksburg, West Virginia to support an existing gas processing plant and reinforce the regional grid. 
We're also planning construction of a new transmission sub-station near Pennsylvania that will support low growth and improve service reliability for more than 40,000 customers of West Penn Power. At the EEI Conference last November, we told you that we have identified about $15 billion in incremental transmission projects in 2018 and beyond, providing both improved customer service and their long-term and sustainable growth platform for our company. 
Let's shift gears now and look at our competitive business. Gadgets we continue to take with regard to our more conservative strategy have been very effective at reducing the overall risk in this business. While our open position is subject to market movement, we are structuring the business to be more predictable and self-sustaining. Our conservative approach will better protect us in the event of extreme weather on unplanned outages at major generating facility. We are projecting this business to be cash flow positive each year over to 2015 through 2018 period, using conservative assumptions. 
I've been asked numerous times about the possibility of divesting this business. Frankly, at this point in time, it doesn't make sense while we were at or hopefully near the bottom of the market, to sell these assets at the lowest value they will likely ever have. In addition, capacity market reforms and pending changes to the treatment of demand response are likely to provide near-term value for this business. Once these moving pieces play out, we should have a much better picture of what we can expect from our competitive business going forward.  At this point, it remains a core business for FirstEnergy. However, we continue to monitor closely the financial performance of some of our individual generating units, particularly those located in Western PJM. While the low market revenue are built into our financial models, several of our units continue to struggle to run economically. 
The strategies we have in place in all 3 of our business segments are sound. They are the right priorities for our company at this time and in this environment and we will continue to refine them as conditions require or opportunities emerge. Along the way, we intend to provide clear communication about our challenges, opportunities, strategies and goals. I'm sure you have many questions at the end of this call and we have a full investor meeting scheduled coming up. I will make myself available as often as necessary to ensure we address all of your questions. I also hope to get to know many of you more in the next several months. For those of you who are not yet familiar with my style, I was trained as an engineer to solve problems. My career at FirstEnergy has been focused on customers and looking for sound, long-term regions. Our distribution and transmission businesses have been  my main focus, although I have the opportunity to oversee our competitive business for a couple of years as well. As I mentioned earlier, in my mind, the best investments, like the ones we're making in our transmission business are those that provide both customers and shareholders with real value. It's our responsibility to provide customers with safe, reliable, affordable and clean electricity and my philosophy is the commitment to these principles reflect in both our decision-making and our management style is good business. 
Lastly, I believe very strongly in transparent communications, whether to employees, customers, regulators or the financial community, that means saying what we know, when we know it. That's why we decided the right earnings guidance sooner than originally expected. Looking forward, we will remain focused on long-term shareholder value, executing our regulated growth plans and taking a conservative approach to our competitive business. At the same time, we will continue to evolving to meet the needs of our customers who rely on electricity to power their businesses and every day lives. My priority to move FirstEnergy to its next period of growth and success, benefiting our customers, employees and investors. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jim for a short review of 2014 financial results and additional details on our earnings guidance. Following Jim's remarks, we'll open the call to your questions and we should have ample time to address whatever you would like to talk about.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported 2014 fourth quarter operating earnings of $0.80 per share and full year operating earnings of $2.56 per share, which was at the upper end of our guidance range. It was a strong quarter a
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we reported 2014 fourth quarter operating earnings of $0.80 per share and full year operating earnings of $2.56 per share, which was at the upper end of our guidance range. It was a strong quarter and a solid year overall with numerous achievements. And somewhat of a change in the past practice, I won't cover the results for the quarter in detail by segment as that information is available in the consolidated report or from our IR team. Instead, I will speak to the major drivers and events while leaving more time for Q&A. 
For the fourth quarter of 2014, GAAP results were a loss of $0.73 per share. This includes special items of $1.53 per share, of which $1.23 is related to our annual pension and OPEB mark-to-market adjustment and as a non-cash item. This adjustment primary reflects a 75 basis points decline in the discount rate than revise mortality assumptions used to measure our obligation. 
Moving now to our fourth quarter operating earnings drivers. Consistent with the guidance we provided at EEI in November, the FirstEnergy consolidated effective tax rate was 21.6% in the fourth quarter of 2014, predominantly reflecting a tax benefit associated with the resolution of state tax position. This drove a quarter-over-quarter benefit of $0.12 per share, of which $0.10 was included in the corporate segment. 
At our regulated utilities, overall distribution deliveries decreased fourth quarter earnings, $0.01 per share, total deliveries were down slightly primarily driven by milder weather, which drove a 2.5% reduction in residential sales quarter-over-quarter. Industrial sales were up 1.8%, that's 6 consecutive quarter of growth in that sector. 
On the transmission side, we reported fourth quarter operating earnings of $0.14 per share, in line with our expectations as we ramped up our Energizing the Future initiative. At our competitive operations, results came in slightly better than expected for the quarter. Commodity margin was down $0.08 per share, primarily due to lower contract sales that resulted from the change in retail strategy, as well as mild weather. These factors were partially offset by higher capacity revenues related to the increase in the auction clearing prices. 
Let's move now to a short overview of some of the key earnings drivers for 2014, which included a 6% earnings improvement in our transmission segment year-over-year as we've launched our Energizing the Future initiative. On the competitive side of the business, we experienced a year-over-year earnings decline of $0.51 per share due to extreme weather events or early in 2014, partially offset by the actions we put into place your position our sales portfolio and effectively hedge our generation by reducing weather sensitive load. 
Adjusted EBITDA was $653 million, in line with our expectations. At our regulated distribution utilities, we reported 2014 operating earnings of $1.93 per share, in line with the midpoint guidance we provided the November. We saw the full benefit of the West Virginia asset transfer, but also rising expenses for maintenance, depreciation, general taxes and interest without commensurate recovery in rates. However, as Chuck said, the rates that we expect to be effective in 2015 will reset the baseline for a majority of our utilities. 
Distribution deliveries increased 1% compared to 2013 on both an actual and weather adjusted basis. Industrial sales were up each quarter and ended the year up 2%. At our Corporate segment, we benefited from multiple tax initiatives and ended the year with an effective income tax rate of 29.3%. As we have previously discussed, we anticipate an effective tax rate of approximately 37% to 38% in 2015. 
Let's now move to a discussion of some of the 2015 operating earnings guidance details. On the regulated utility side, which is where we believe most estimates did not fully account for the increases in ongoing expenses such as depreciation, interest and taxes, we expect a midpoint of $1.82 per share. This includes new rigs in West Virginia, which will be effective this month and our expectation for new rates in Pennsylvania, which will be effective in May based on the pending settlement. For New Jersey, we assume revenues neutral to 2014 level, but included $0.08 per share for amortization of storm cost for both in 2011 and 2012 storms. 
We expect moderate low growth and distribution sales of about 1%. Commodity margin at our competitive operations is expected to increase by $0.44 per share in 2015 compared to 2014, primarily due to higher ATSI capacity prices. For 2015, our committed sales currently are $0.67 [indiscernible] competitive business has been revised $875 million to $950 million, a slight decrease from our previous range given the drop in power prices since November. 
At our Transmission segment. This year, we expect an uplift of $0.11 per share related to the implementation of forward-looking formula rate as requested in our FERC filing and higher rate base at both ATSI and Trail. And although FERC has initiated an inquiry related to our ATSI ROE, we anticipate the range for that segment should accommodate the outcome of that process. 
At Corporate, a combination of a more normal effective tax rate, coupled with increased net financing cost is expected to reduce 2015 operating earnings by $0.42 per share, in line with the drivers we provided at EEI. Last evening, we published detailed information regarding our 2015 guidance on our fact book, which is posted on our website. 
With that, I'd like to open the call for your questions.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015

componenttext: As promised, we have 35 minutes left for questions.

componenttextpreview: Jim, I have a question on the O&M expense at the regulated utility. So it seems to go up $0.08 in 2015 and then in your drivers in 2016, it looks like it's flat. I was just wondering, what's causing the increase in '15 and maybe what's the normalized run
componenttext: Jim, I have a question on the O&M expense at the regulated utility. So it seems to go up $0.08 in 2015 and then in your drivers in 2016, it looks like it's flat. I was just wondering, what's causing the increase in '15 and maybe what's the normalized run rate on a percentage basis for increases going forward?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Going forward, Neel, I'm would say our O&M is going to be pretty much consistent with what we're reflecting in 2015. And 2015, we're seeing some additional O&M expenses associated with some of our rate filings and vegetation management, mostly. That will
componenttext: Going forward, Neel, I'm would say our O&M is going to be pretty much consistent with what we're reflecting in 2015. And 2015, we're seeing some additional O&M expenses associated with some of our rate filings and vegetation management, mostly. That will be the primary driver.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: And vegetation management means money reclaiming our right of ways and expanding our right of ways which has been captured [indiscernible] for your term cycle, which is going to shift some of that back to O&M.
componenttext: And vegetation management means money reclaiming our right of ways and expanding our right of ways which has been captured [indiscernible] for your term cycle, which is going to shift some of that back to O&M.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. So in 2016, it looks like it's kind of neutral. I mean do you expect it to be flat or do you expect kind of a consistent percentage increases '14 to '15 between '15 and '16?
componenttext: Right. So in 2016, it looks like it's kind of neutral. I mean do you expect it to be flat or do you expect kind of a consistent percentage increases '14 to '15 between '15 and '16?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015

componenttext: No. In 2016, Neel, we expect that O&M to flat in 2015.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then is there any kind of update on the timing of the high OPPAs as far as when we get a decision and whether that would be before RPM?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then is there any kind of update on the timing of the high OPPAs as far as when we get a decision and whether that would be before RPM?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Leila. Yes, so the procedural schedule flipped in Ohio a little bit. We now have FirstEnergy supplemental testimony being due on March 2, as well as intervenor testimony and staff testimony on March 27 and hearing is on April 13. Given that we've
componenttext: This is Leila. Yes, so the procedural schedule flipped in Ohio a little bit. We now have FirstEnergy supplemental testimony being due on March 2, as well as intervenor testimony and staff testimony on March 27 and hearing is on April 13. Given that we've asked for -- originally sked for April 8 position date, obviously that is not going to happen. But from our standpoint, I still think we are in's a good place. Originally we have asked for the April 8 day to accommodate two things. If you think about it from an FES perspective, FES need to know how to hedge it so we need a reasonable period of time to allow FES to be put into position to sell it. And also with regard to the RPM auction. I think given the schedule, the way it is now, FES is going to have the bid those units in along with the rest of the competitive generation and it's just kind of a missed opportunity for the utility side to do that. But again, I don't think that's a critical thing. It is would've been a nice to that kind of thing. So that's with respect to the schedule for us. As you may know, AP has a case dealing with PPA coming up. I understand the decision to probably come out in the next 2 to 3 weeks or so and I'm hopeful that will bode well for a decision in our case.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Dan Akers of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question is from Dan Akers of Crédit Suisse.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chuck, I think Jim hit it well that probably a lot of us on the Street was surprised by some of the expense lines at the Utility. If you look at the earned ROEs with different jurisdictions, how do you think those ROEs look in 2015 versus what you expect
componenttext: Chuck, I think Jim hit it well that probably a lot of us on the Street was surprised by some of the expense lines at the Utility. If you look at the earned ROEs with different jurisdictions, how do you think those ROEs look in 2015 versus what you expect going forward. I mean are you going to see improvement in ROEs beyond this year or are we normalized at this ROE level?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well Dan, here's what I'd say. Obviously, I think, given fiscal policy in our country, there's going to continue to be pressure on ROEs as long as interest rates stay low. But absent regulatory action on our part, I don't see any way that those are going
componenttext: Well Dan, here's what I'd say. Obviously, I think, given fiscal policy in our country, there's going to continue to be pressure on ROEs as long as interest rates stay low. But absent regulatory action on our part, I don't see any way that those are going to change. So once we get through Pennsylvania, we figure out where we end up with ATSI and we get through New Jersey. I think we're going to be in a pretty stable place there and I expect later this year when we do any analyst meeting, that we'll be able to give you a little more transparency into what those are, company by company other than where we kind of did the rate making it kind of a blackbox type environment. So hopefully we'll give you more clarity on that later this summer.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe I asked a little clumsy than I meant to. From an earned ROE perspective, if you look at the different utilities particularly with your rate cases having gotten resolved, should the earned realized ROEs kind of level out at what you're expecting in 2
componenttext: Maybe I asked a little clumsy than I meant to. From an earned ROE perspective, if you look at the different utilities particularly with your rate cases having gotten resolved, should the earned realized ROEs kind of level out at what you're expecting in 2015 guidance or do you look at things in 2016 and 2017 to kind of allow your earned ROEs to improve?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would think they're going to certainly level out at where we're at and 2015 and I expect over time there will be some modest improvement.
componenttext: I would think they're going to certainly level out at where we're at and 2015 and I expect over time there will be some modest improvement.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess, Jim, on the operating expenses being higher on the Utility side than we expected. The pension and the OPEB and depreciation expenses seem to stand out from our math. Can you just talk about what was underlying some of those increas
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess, Jim, on the operating expenses being higher on the Utility side than we expected. The pension and the OPEB and depreciation expenses seem to stand out from our math. Can you just talk about what was underlying some of those increases year-on-year and how we should think about those going forward?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me start with the pension OPEB line, Dan. That's primarily driven by the absence of a credit that is expiring over the '14, '15 time frame. And then you have slightly higher pension expense associated with the mortality tables. So that would grow
componenttext: Yes. Let me start with the pension OPEB line, Dan. That's primarily driven by the absence of a credit that is expiring over the '14, '15 time frame. And then you have slightly higher pension expense associated with the mortality tables. So that would grow the reduction in that line. From a -- increase in what I'd say, the depreciation in property taxes. When I look at distribution -- that's pretty consistent year-over-year. If you look at '13 to '14 depreciation property taxes increased about $0.09. We're showing about an $0.08 increase, '15 to '16. And when you think about it, we're spending about $1.4 billion, $1.3 billion annually at our distribution company. And we have about $650 million of depreciation. So we're spending more on our depreciation there. So I would look for that type of a consistent increase in depreciation in property taxes. From the transmission side, we showed a increase in depreciation property taxes, about $0.03, '13 to '14. And that was showing the ramp-up of our Energizing the Future program. We spent $1.4 billion in capital in '14. We're expecting to spend just about $1 billion in 2015. So that $0.11 increase in property tax is really associated with that increased capital and essentially the timing of when it goes into service.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just one last question. Just on the transmission side with the CapEx down this year versus last year, I know note that was part of the plan you laid out in the fall, but because of the smaller projects what could motivate you guys for you to spend m
componenttext: Okay. Just one last question. Just on the transmission side with the CapEx down this year versus last year, I know note that was part of the plan you laid out in the fall, but because of the smaller projects what could motivate you guys for you to spend my money in '15 than you've budgeted so far?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think we're going to spend more money in '15 than we budgeted. So I wouldn't want to lead you with that impression. One of the critical aspects of that plan quite frankly is getting the workforce to be able to construct these projects and there is
componenttext: I don't think we're going to spend more money in '15 than we budgeted. So I wouldn't want to lead you with that impression. One of the critical aspects of that plan quite frankly is getting the workforce to be able to construct these projects and there is a constraint on that across our nation. But we have locked in through a partnership with a workforce that will be available to FirstEnergy well into the future. And I think that it makes sense to just approach this in a kind of steady predictable fashion. The drop off from '14 to '15 is due to the fact that we had a number of reliability projects that PJM ordered as the result of the Lake plant closings that we're finishing up and putting into service earlier this year.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Paul Patterson from Glenrock Associates.
componenttext: The next question is from Paul Patterson from Glenrock Associates.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015

componenttext: On the $0.30 for transmission that you guys are projecting for 2015, how much of that is in the ATSI forward treatment that you guys are expecting? And just on that FERC order, as I recall, my understanding was it really haven't signed off on your treatment. Correct me if I'm wrong. I know the settlement discussion was encouraged. I think it's still going on. Can you give us any flavor on that as well in the context of the

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is Leila. I'll answer the latter question first and then I'll turn it over to Jim. So you're correct we are in the settlement process associated with that. There has been no set procedural schedule although if things stay in line, you might expect a
componenttext: This is Leila. I'll answer the latter question first and then I'll turn it over to Jim. So you're correct we are in the settlement process associated with that. There has been no set procedural schedule although if things stay in line, you might expect a decision in that case maybe late this year slipping into the first quarter of the following year. With regard to the rate, they have not the forward-looking, what they did is put the rate into effect subject to a refund. So January 1, we started. I think the refund date was something like the 12th or 13th of January. So that's where it stands from a procedural schedule standpoint.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Paul, to your first question, that $0.30 uptick in revenue, the majority of that would be associated with ATSI in the forward-looking test year.
componenttext: And Paul, to your first question, that $0.30 uptick in revenue, the majority of that would be associated with ATSI in the forward-looking test year.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: But do you guys feel confident, I mean with respect to your settlement discussions and what have you about the FERC test treatment, Leila, is that fair enough to say?
componenttext: But do you guys feel confident, I mean with respect to your settlement discussions and what have you about the FERC test treatment, Leila, is that fair enough to say?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think if you look at past, present and at FERC, I think the forward-looking test year, part of it, even though that is an issue, that the party is raised, is something that from my standpoint I feel very comfortable on. I mean some of the other things t
componenttext: I think if you look at past, present and at FERC, I think the forward-looking test year, part of it, even though that is an issue, that the party is raised, is something that from my standpoint I feel very comfortable on. I mean some of the other things they are planning this is them, they're also looking at the protocols for true-up. So from my standpoint, given how Chuck described what it is we're doing and the reliability aspect of this, I feel very comfortable where we are. The one thing we have always highlighted is the rate of return and the fact that we thought that would be an issue and notwithstanding that, we felt it appropriate to go in with the formula rate. If you want to think about it, every 100 basis points is about $16 million in. And so if you can look at past you can do your own calculations with regard to that.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Paul, I just want to point out, I'm sure you understand this. But because the 2014 expenditures were in a lagging rate mechanism and now the 2015 expenditures are in a forward-looking mechanism, what you're seeing in terms of the shift in earnings from '1
componenttext: Paul, I just want to point out, I'm sure you understand this. But because the 2014 expenditures were in a lagging rate mechanism and now the 2015 expenditures are in a forward-looking mechanism, what you're seeing in terms of the shift in earnings from '14 to '15 really is 2 years worth of expenditures. So that's not the number that you're going to expect to see going forward.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks for the clarity, guys. And then Chuck, you mentioned in your remarks that you wanted, I believe the merchant business to be more self-sustaining and also that you thought of the market was at a very low price and low power prices or what hav
componenttext: Great. Thanks for the clarity, guys. And then Chuck, you mentioned in your remarks that you wanted, I believe the merchant business to be more self-sustaining and also that you thought of the market was at a very low price and low power prices or what have you. It will just be the wrong time to divest the business if that was the case. And I guess the question I have is, A, if you're market outlook change, would you be willing to perhaps look at breaking all these companies And then what's your appetite for additional investments perhaps in merchant? Just in general, how do you see the merchant arm of this business, which is clearly very different than the rest of the business, how do you see that strategically going forward? Did you see possibility of a spin-off or just in general, how we should think about how you're really looking at this business and what you might do strategically to enhance value?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: So here's how I'm thinking about it. And I've told several others when I've been asked this question. I learned a long time ago, never say never and never say always. So things can change. But for now, we're looking at running that business in a mode wher
componenttext: So here's how I'm thinking about it. And I've told several others when I've been asked this question. I learned a long time ago, never say never and never say always. So things can change. But for now, we're looking at running that business in a mode where I remain cash flow positive, where we use those market changes that are coming to take that cash and begin retiring some of that holding company debt that's associated with that business. And over time, put that business into a position where we can have more flexibility in how we look at it. And then if you can tell me what the market's going to be elected 2 years, 3 years, 4 years, I think I can answer what I would do depending on what that market is like. But I did think anybody can tell us what that's going to be. So right now, we're heads down. We're committed to running a cash flow positive and we're committed to derisking it, so it doesn't continue to be the conversation when 80% of our company is regulated and generating absent today and getting everybody kind of in line with where we're at, generating consistent, predictable regulated earnings. So that's the plan.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015

componenttext: Manny, before we move forward, I was handed a note when I was giving Dan an explanation on the increases on depreciation year-over-year. I said an increase '16 versus '15. I should've said 2015 versus 2014.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015

componenttext: So I wanted to go back again to the distribution earnings because I mean you're clearly missing a piece here. So you just gone through rate cases in Pennsylvania and New Jersey and West Virginia. What is your cost structure going into these rate cases? You showed us what is the pretax impact of the rate case settlement of decisions and yet we have all of the $0.25 plus drag from higher cost in the distribution side. Shouldn't that have been already reflected in the rate cases that you have gone through? And also is there been attempt to basically reset the base for future growth of this business and as such, there's incremental O&M spending that's basically not recurring?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Angie, yes, this is Jim. Some of the expenses that we had incurred was prepared for these rate filings that we had. As I've said earlier, we would expect that our O&M is going to be held flat going into next year and we will be realizing the full impact o
componenttext: Angie, yes, this is Jim. Some of the expenses that we had incurred was prepared for these rate filings that we had. As I've said earlier, we would expect that our O&M is going to be held flat going into next year and we will be realizing the full impact of all of those rate filings next year. As Chuck said earlier, I would look at 2015 as our of base line that we are going to start growing those distribution earnings from that point and we'll be said to provide more clarity on that at the analyst day meeting that we have.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can you at least give us a sense of the growth that other regulated utilities can offer? I mean is this a meaningful step up starting in '16? For distribution?
componenttext: Okay. Can you at least give us a sense of the growth that other regulated utilities can offer? I mean is this a meaningful step up starting in '16? For distribution?

componenttext: At this point, we're not giving any type of 2016 guidance, but this is the baseline that we would expect to start showing growth at our distribution utilities. I don't think we're going to put a percent out there yet until we fully understand what's reflected in all of the regulatory outcomes and that we're comfortable and confident that we'll be able to deliver on that.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015

componenttext: We've got some work to do here. We have a settlement, but it has been approved by the PA regulators so I don't think it's there for us to assume that we still got work to do in New Jersey and [indiscernible] once we get all those answers.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] you all are fairly physically close to a lot of the shale gas activity and we've seen a lot of development on shale gas. Just at a high level interested in your market take in terms of what the growth in shale gas really means [indiscernib
componenttext: [indiscernible] you all are fairly physically close to a lot of the shale gas activity and we've seen a lot of development on shale gas. Just at a high level interested in your market take in terms of what the growth in shale gas really means [indiscernible] Chuck's earlier comment that you're relatively bullish on power prices relative to the fourth quarter. I was just curious how you think about the dynamics from the shale gas that we're seeing being developed right around your territory?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: First of all, I'm not sure what I said to make you think I was bullish on power prices because that's quite to the contrary. I [indiscernible] in different ways. The first way is on those forward price curves and we actually had [indiscernible] uptick in
componenttext: First of all, I'm not sure what I said to make you think I was bullish on power prices because that's quite to the contrary. I [indiscernible] in different ways. The first way is on those forward price curves and we actually had [indiscernible] uptick in those forward price curves, so we are structuring our competitive business around those forwards as we know. The other side of that coin is, it's the economic development engine that's driving growth in our territory and over the next few years, we are expected to connect over 1,000 megawatts of new load directly attributed to the midstream part of that business. There are discussions underway about up to 3 cracker plants in our region. If any or all of those come to fruition, I think those [indiscernible] that there's some congestion in the gas markets that's going on right now, but there's also roughly $20 billion worth of gas transmission projects that are under construction and expected to go in service over the next few years that will release some of that congestion and eliminate some of the basis difference between our zone and the rest of the country and that might have a modest change. But all in all, we're planning to run a regulated business around the market forward as we see them today.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just wanted to touch base on your hedging strategy given everything you've seen in the market. Any changes in terms of your thinking in terms of the volume that you'd like to hedge or given what you've said about sort of your market outlook. Any chang
componenttext: And just wanted to touch base on your hedging strategy given everything you've seen in the market. Any changes in terms of your thinking in terms of the volume that you'd like to hedge or given what you've said about sort of your market outlook. Any changes we should expect in terms of how you all think about hedging your generation fleet going forward?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say no and what I said in my prepared remarks was we structure that business in a way where we are trying to expose risks to volatility as associated to weather and to kind of protect ourselves against an unplanned generator average. So we have th
componenttext: I would say no and what I said in my prepared remarks was we structure that business in a way where we are trying to expose risks to volatility as associated to weather and to kind of protect ourselves against an unplanned generator average. So we have the ability to generate 80 million to 85 million megawatt hours a year. We're going to sell something less than that, so that as the load fluctuates with weather, our committed load fluctuates with weather and/or we have issues that at any of our plants, we have the ability to cover ourselves. That will -- I understand we're likely giving up some earnings potential from that business by taking risk out of it, but as I said earlier, I'd rather it could more predictable, more stable and get it out of the conversation as much as I can so we can talk about the type of company FirstEnergy really is which is a large regulated utility with 6 million costumers.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very clear. And just lastly, very briefly, we've seen some relatively extreme weather through the wintertime. In general, how's the fleet performed through this sort of this winter period that you've seen? Have you been satisfied with performance o
componenttext: That's very clear. And just lastly, very briefly, we've seen some relatively extreme weather through the wintertime. In general, how's the fleet performed through this sort of this winter period that you've seen? Have you been satisfied with performance of the fleet and anything compared to sort of prior year in terms of performance trends?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say that our fleet has performed very well. The markets have not. So we have 2 units at the Bruce Mansfield plant that didn't run for 6 days in the last 2 weeks because the LMP at those plants, we couldn't make money. So we didn't run them. But th
componenttext: I would say that our fleet has performed very well. The markets have not. So we have 2 units at the Bruce Mansfield plant that didn't run for 6 days in the last 2 weeks because the LMP at those plants, we couldn't make money. So we didn't run them. But the plants are available. They're running well. Our generating team has done an amazing job between last year and this year getting ready for this winter.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Julien Dumoulin-Smith of UBS.
componenttext: The next question is from Julien Dumoulin-Smith of UBS.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I really wanted to focus on the transmission side of the business, specifically the guidance. What are you guys assuming in terms of earned ROE and I know it may be awkward in the context of your pending case for ATSI. But can you give us a sense on how m
componenttext: I really wanted to focus on the transmission side of the business, specifically the guidance. What are you guys assuming in terms of earned ROE and I know it may be awkward in the context of your pending case for ATSI. But can you give us a sense on how much lag is embedded in that number and as you turn towards the forward test year and implementing that kind of run rate for '16, what kind of improvement should we be thinking about there and what's ultimately reflected in '15 specifically?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. So I'm not sure if I got all of those. Some going to answer the first question that you can answer and asked them 1 at the time, it's easier for me to follow. But the first question on -- we get that question a lot of what are we assuming about
componenttext: All right. So I'm not sure if I got all of those. Some going to answer the first question that you can answer and asked them 1 at the time, it's easier for me to follow. But the first question on -- we get that question a lot of what are we assuming about ATSI's rate of return going forward and here's how I view this: We just got FERC's approval on January 1 to move forward. There' are a case that that's going to be had and is a settlement process that's going to be had and my view is we're going to go into those arguing why 12.38% makes sense going forward, assimilating the type of investment and reliability that I believe FERC should want. And that's our going-in position. Anything from there, if I give you a number, then we're going to be negotiating from that number. So we're not going to give you a number. We're going to go into those settlement and we're going to make the best case we can to make sure that we get the right return for our investors so that we can continue making these investments in the way that we are.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: But from a regulatory lag perspective, what are you assuming, if you can talk...
componenttext: But from a regulatory lag perspective, what are you assuming, if you can talk...

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015

componenttext: Regulatory lag, we're assuming forward-looking rates.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it's not necessary improvement next year as you have a full year or what have you?
componenttext: Okay. So it's not necessary improvement next year as you have a full year or what have you?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: And it turns for the outlook for transmission CapEx, how are you feeling about flowing dollars in the transmission versus distribution? Can you kind of elaborate a little bit on where you see capital going in the future and then subsequently I know we dis
componenttext: And it turns for the outlook for transmission CapEx, how are you feeling about flowing dollars in the transmission versus distribution? Can you kind of elaborate a little bit on where you see capital going in the future and then subsequently I know we discussed this before, but on distribution side what kind of future investments do you see now that you've gone through or about to go through all of the estate utility rate cases?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let's take transmission first. We've told you about $4.2 billion over a 4-year period that we're in the second year of. It was $1.4 billion in the first year, it's $900-and-some million in the second year. After 2 years, we'll be right on track to be h
componenttext: So let's take transmission first. We've told you about $4.2 billion over a 4-year period that we're in the second year of. It was $1.4 billion in the first year, it's $900-and-some million in the second year. After 2 years, we'll be right on track to be halfway through that and for '16 and '17, that's going to be the number. We have $15 billion worth of projects in addition to those that are in the 4-year plan that we can execute, that hopefully I'll be in a position that when we talk to you later this year to articulate kind of more of a long-term strategy for transmission and what we're planning to do there. But for the first table future do numbers we've given you is what my plans are. And I think one of the things that I had to start doing is saying what we're going to do and then doing what we say. So I don't expect any change in that over the next couple of years. On the distribution front, the rate cases in Pennsylvania are a huge step. It rebasis those utilities and it was a necessary step if we decide to make reliability improvement investments in Pennsylvania. Pennsylvania has a methodology that's available to us, called the that we can make investments. But as I told you when you came in, we've got to get through these rate cases first and then we'll make decisions there. And then in my prepared remarks, I said once we get through the base rate case in New Jersey, then I look forward to sitting down with the BPU and working together to figure out how we make JCP&L stronger going forward. In Ohio, we have a DCR mechanism that we have been using to invest in those utilities. So later this year, I know you want numbers, I'm not prepared to give you numbers today. But later this year, I think we can layout a strategy of how much and where we plan to invest to start using our distribution utilities to improve source to customers and improve the picture for the shareholders at the same time.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your interest in using the DISC [ph] mechanism to be clear, in Pennsylvania?
componenttext: And your interest in using the DISC [ph] mechanism to be clear, in Pennsylvania?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we will look at it once we're done and then decide, is that the best way and does it allow the right investments. Because more importantly to me is making the right investments that truly benefit customers and if that makes more sense to make them
componenttext: I think we will look at it once we're done and then decide, is that the best way and does it allow the right investments. Because more importantly to me is making the right investments that truly benefit customers and if that makes more sense to make them and just have traditional rate cases, then we'll go that way. But to me, we have the layout but the plan is for customers first and make the right investment but that can be done under the DISC, then the DISC would be a smart way to do it.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Anthony of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question is from Anthony of Jefferies.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: More of like I guess a long-term view question or I guess earlier in your remarks, you said that you're not interested in selling the generation assets and then maybe paraphrasing just you thought it was kind of the bottom of the market. But if I think 3
componenttext: More of like I guess a long-term view question or I guess earlier in your remarks, you said that you're not interested in selling the generation assets and then maybe paraphrasing just you thought it was kind of the bottom of the market. But if I think 3 to 5 years, if you're locking of the assets now in some type of regulatory agreement, R&D working that in at these depressed prices and don't -- 3 to 5 years will not be able to benefit if there's a power price recovery?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me opine a little bit on what's going on in Ohio and I am of to belief that long term, those states that remain fully regulated when you have the ability to optimize between generation, transmission and distribution, you're going to serve customers
componenttext: So let me opine a little bit on what's going on in Ohio and I am of to belief that long term, those states that remain fully regulated when you have the ability to optimize between generation, transmission and distribution, you're going to serve customers best. Some of our states chose to go to competitive markets. This whole discussion in Ohio is around whether or not we trust regulators better to look out for the long-term interest of customers or whether we trust markets better to look out for long-term interest for customers. Those states that are net importers of generation end up with the highest cost and don't have the ability to optimize between those 3 segments. So if the PPA is successful, we're basically taking those plants and turning it over to the regulators to regulate them again. They all have a chance to look at how we run them, to look at the prudency of our expenses, but we are saying, I think, we trust regulated to look out for the future Ohio more than we did the markets today.

componenttext: The next question is from Brian Chin of Bank of America.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: About a year ago, the management team had expressed a possible interest in looking at the REIT structure for transmission growth opportunities and given now that there is an energy out there that, you can see with the cost of capital is like, I just wante
componenttext: About a year ago, the management team had expressed a possible interest in looking at the REIT structure for transmission growth opportunities and given now that there is an energy out there that, you can see with the cost of capital is like, I just wanted to see if you could give us an update in a sense of that and, Chuck, also any comments in your perspective?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure. We are always looking at any option that's out there, but I'm not sure that we saw at that time or see today, any real benefit to a REIT for our company. Our company is a little complex in terms of we've got transmission that's inside utilit
componenttext: I'm not sure. We are always looking at any option that's out there, but I'm not sure that we saw at that time or see today, any real benefit to a REIT for our company. Our company is a little complex in terms of we've got transmission that's inside utilities, transmission that's inside ATSI and transmission that's inside TrAILCo, the real estate is owned by the utilities and I just think it's a distraction that would take a lot of time and effort of the management team [indiscernible] to figure out that we don't need to be looking at right now [indiscernible]

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: So is that really the criteria that we should be thinking about from a pipeline perspective here?
componenttext: So is that really the criteria that we should be thinking about from a pipeline perspective here?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we have an emerging generation business, cash flow positive for the next 4 years at market forwards as we know them and with capacity as we know it. So that's not ago, that's where we're at. As we see the changes that are happening with the capacity ma
componenttext: So we have an emerging generation business, cash flow positive for the next 4 years at market forwards as we know them and with capacity as we know it. So that's not ago, that's where we're at. As we see the changes that are happening with the capacity market reforms, that's going to be additive. We've put ourselves in a position with our generating fleet that were not forced to generate because we have load commitments. We've got significant amount of our generation that's going to be market driven generation. That gives us the ability, like I said 2 weeks ago, to say it Mansfield is not in the money, we're not going to run it and lose money. So we're going to optimize it and that optimization is something that we're going to do day in, day out. We're going to do day in our kind of more as we look at any options on the retail side as new customer opportunities present themselves. But the goal is, it's cash flow positive and we're there. And then beyond that, we want to obviously drive it more cash flow positive so that they can start additional flex ability in that part of the business down the road.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015

componenttext: Certainly. The final question comes from the line of Michael Lapides of Goldman Sachs.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just thinking about the balance sheet and capital structure. You guys did a really good job 1.5 years ago of reducing the debt levels at the competitive business. You now are in a position where you've got a lot of debt at the holding company level and a
componenttext: Just thinking about the balance sheet and capital structure. You guys did a really good job 1.5 years ago of reducing the debt levels at the competitive business. You now are in a position where you've got a lot of debt at the holding company level and a lot of it is short term or floating rate. Many economists would argue that short-term debt is probably at a total time lows and that directionally short-term is like we are heading higher. Do you have any thoughts in terms of how you can deal with the significant amount of short-term debt upon the balance sheet, meaning whether you would term it out and therefore kind of a lock in long-term interest rate for that and kind of give yourself some multi-year certainty at that or would you potentially pay it off and if so, how would you -- where would you receive the proceeds or how would you generate the proceeds to pay down some of the debt?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2015
componenttextpreview: Michael, at this point, I think [indiscernible] the rate case, the potential for the capacity performance product, I think that will give us a much clearer sense of what our cash projections will be going forward. At this point, we have no plans to term o
componenttext: Michael, at this point, I think [indiscernible] the rate case, the potential for the capacity performance product, I think that will give us a much clearer sense of what our cash projections will be going forward. At this point, we have no plans to term out any of the long-term debt that's sitting at the holdco. I do agree with you that we are carrying more debt at that level than either Chuck and I are comfortable with. But as we lay out our long-term plan going forward, it will be our intention to strengthen the balance sheet. And with that, reducing some of that bad debt at the holding company. But at this point, I cannot give you a specific plan to do that until we know some of the outcomes of these major initiatives.

componenttext: Got it. Thanks, Jim.

componenttext: Well, I'd like to thank you all for your continued support of FirstEnergy. And I think, our goal today was to give you a clear and transparent view of our company and to build a foundation for our growth strategy that we will lay out in more detail later this year in the analyst meeting. I'm proud to have the opportunity to take over for Tony. I'm proud of our employees at FirstEnergy because I truly believe they're what makes our company strong. And I'm thankful for our 6 million costumers and obviously, all of our investors. Take care, everyone.
