I would now like to turn the conference over to your host Meghan Beringer, Director of Investor Relations for FirstEnergy Corp. Thank you, Ms. Beringer, you may now begin.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kevin. Welcome to our First Quarter Earnings Call. Today we make various forward-looking statements regarding revenue, earnings, performance strategies and prospects. This statements are based on current expectations and are subject to risks and u
componenttext: Thanks, Kevin. Welcome to our First Quarter Earnings Call. Today we make various forward-looking statements regarding revenue, earnings, performance strategies and prospects. This statements are based on current expectations and are subject to risks and uncertainties. Factors that could cause actual results or outcomes to differ materially from those indicated by such statements can be found on the investors section of our website under the earnings information link and in our SEC filings. We will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures are also available on our website. Participating in today's call are Chuck Jones, President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Pearson, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Leila Vespoli, Executive Vice President, Markets and Chief Legal Officer; Donny Schneider, President of FirstEnergy Solutions; Jason Pigott, our Corporate Assistant and Controller. Steve Staub, Vice President and Treasurer; and Irene Prezelj, Vice President, Investor Relations. Now I will turn the call over to Chuck Jones.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Meghan, and good morning, everyone. It's a pleasure to speak with you today. We had a good quarter and we are off to a great start for the year. Since our last call in February, we have continued our work to position FirstEnergy for solid, predict
componenttext:
Thanks, Meghan, and good morning, everyone. It's a pleasure to speak with you today. We had a good quarter and we are off to a great start for the year. Since our last call in February, we have continued our work to position FirstEnergy for solid, predictable and customer-service-driven aggregate growth. This morning we will talk about our progress on those strategies charges. We will discuss other key initiatives including an important effort that is underway to reduce our cost structure and drive improvements to our balance sheet. And, of course, we will review our first quarter financial results and operational performance. 
Similar to our last call, we intend to keep his prepared remarks brief to allow ample time for your questions before the end of the hour. Our first quarter operating earnings of $0.62 per share are slightly above the top-end of our guidance range, and give us a solid foundation start of the year. We benefited from the growth in our transmission business and solid distribution performance that was assisted by second year of unusually cold weather. Our year-over-year results also reflect the actions we began taking in the second quarter of 2014 to reposition the retail sales portfolio and our competitive business. For the past year, we have talked about the extreme weather events of 2014's first quarter and the impact those conditions had on our competitive business and our strategy. The first quarter of 2015 was even colder, with heating-degree days totaling 21% above normal and 2% higher than 2014. The PGM market also set a new winter peak of 144,000 megawatts exceeding the previous winter peak, which was set in January of 2014. In our competitive business, however, the difference in our results between this winter and last is striking. This improvements speaks to the benefit of our more conservative strategy, which includes 3 major components. First, selling no more than we produce in order to maintain an open position of at least 10 million to 20 million megawatt-hours annually to protect against extreme weather, unplanned outages or a combination of both. As a result of our actions to strategically reduce load obligations, our 2015 retail and the polar obligations are expected to be about 68 million megawatt-hours compared to 99 million megawatt-hours in 2014. Second, reducing exposure to weather sensitive load. From January of 2014 to March of 2015, our overall retail obligations are down nearly 35% on an annualized basis, with much of that coming from serving fewer of the most weather-sensitive residential and small commercial customers. And finally, a more rigorous commitment to economically dispatching our units. This strategy together with improved plant operations helped to mitigate the potential downside from this year's severe first quarter weather and demand conditions. Even though our region experienced 4 more below 0 days this February than last January. As contracts continue to roll off, we expect a further decrease in our annualized retail load obligation through the end of this year and much of the decline will be associated with the most weather-sensitive load. As I have mentioned to many of you previously, we recognized that reducing the risk in the business also means that we are a likely giving up some earnings potential. As we have said, our objective is to make the competitive business more stable as we focus our efforts on growth in the regulated businesses. In that regard, the last few months have been a busy period for our Energizing the Future transmission investment program. We are nearing completion of projects that are designed to maintain service reliability in the wake of plant activations in the northern Ohio. Those plants to cease operations for good on April 15. These projects included the Bruce Mann project, a 195 million, 345 transmission line extending 119 miles from Western Pennsylvania to Suburban Cleveland, scheduled to go in service by June 1.
In addition, we are preparing to energize new 345-kilowatt substation and associated transmission upgrades in Trumbull and Starr counties, which are designed to maintain service rollout reliability in Northern Ohio after the plants are closed. We also continued our work to strengthen the grid to help protected from storms and make network and physical security upgrades. Finally, we are on track with our planned investments on projects that will support the midstream gas operations with about 365 million in the pipeline through 2019.
On the regulatory front, our rate cases in New Jersey and Pennsylvania have concluded. In Pennsylvania, we were pleased that the PUC accepted our rate plant settlements for each of our 4 utilities in the state. The new rates, which will be effective on Sunday, will help our operating companies continue to enhance reliability and service to our Pennsylvania customers. We are looking at further options for customer-focus investments going forward, including the option to possibly requested distribution and system improvement charge to recover the cost of those investments. In New Jersey, we received the recovery of approximately $580 million in cost incurred by JCP for 2012 storms and we are glad to have the long process and uncertainty behind us. Now we look forward to working with the BPU as we set a course for our future infrastructure and reliability investments at JC P&L. 
We've had a good and productive start of the year and we are making solid progress toward our long-term goals. Looking forward, there are still 3 major initiatives underway that will ultimately help shape our company and our strategies going forward. First, in Ohio, the hearing on our relative security plan has been delayed by 60 days and is scheduled to begin on June 15. As you know, in its recent decisions on AEP and cases the PUC ruled that stability related to purchase power agreements similar to our proposal are illegal in Ohio. This was an extremely significant outcome. We believe that our filing includes a robust case for how our proposal benefits utility customers and supports economic development in the state. On May 4, we expect to file supplemental testimony to further demonstrate how our plant maids of factors outlined in the AEP and cases. While we are comfortable with the new schedule set by the PUCO, this schedule will help the timing of our analyst meeting, which we had hoped to have this summer. We believe that it makes sense to host this meeting after we receive a decision in Ohio, which pushes us to sometime later this year.
Second open matter that could have a significant impact on our business, is the PJM capacity performance proposal. PJM has addressed questions into the structure of the product. Pending its standardization, FERC granted PGM request to labor to delay capacity auction to no later than the week of August 10. We appreciate the care and long-term perspective that FERC is taking in its review of this important mechanism and expect that both PJM and FERC are interested in reaching a resolution as soon as possible. In both of these matters, we look forward to final outcome that produces better clarity for our company and produces benefits for electric consumers in our region. On a related item, as you know, we have delayed our decision to construct a new dewatering facility for our 2,400 megawatt in Pennsylvania, while we evaluated the plants future, particularly with respect to the results of the next capacity auction. We will continue to monitor market conditions, but given the current environment, including the auction delay, we think it makes sense to move forward with some early aspects of this project. This work is designed to preserve our ability to continue operations of the plant after December 31, 2016. All costs associated with this project are in our current business plan. We, of course, intend to remain sharply focused on those things that we can control, including our own spending on goods and services, operating expenses and other corporate spending as well as capital expenditures. 
Last month, we launched a cash flow improvement projects intending the capture both immediate and long-term savings opportunities that are meaningful and sustainable. A team led by FES Donny Schneider is working to identify savings and process improvements across the company with a particular emphasis on our generation business. The team is focused on expense reductions, capital expenditures and inventory. We're also working with an outside consultant to examine the significant savings potential in our supply chain. 
With more than $2.5 billion in annual spending in the project scope, we believe that significant cost-savings opportunities are available, while continuing to successfully serve the needs of our organization, customers and employees. I will note that workforce and benefit reductions are not included in the scope of the project. In all, we're targeting $50 million in savings this year and an additional $150 million in 2016, reaching a run rate of $200 million by 2017. We expect that the savings will be split about evenly between O&M expenses and capital expenditures, and help us create sustainable levels for the future. By appropriately addressing our cost structure, we can help direct our future and move FirstEnergy to point that are of fundamental operations make the company stronger, while improving the balance sheet overtime. 
We are off to a solid start in 2015. Our early financial results together with our progress on our strategic initiatives are building a solid foundation for the year and for the future of our company. These results and our outlook for the remainder of the year continue to support 2015 operating guidance in the range of $2.40 to $2.70 per share. Consistent with the leadership philosophy I've shared with many of you, I would like to narrow the gap between our GAAP and non-GAAP results. While some differences are expected, we are diligently focused on earnings quality. 
Now, we will turn the call over to Jim for a brief review of our first quarter financial results, and then we will open the call to questions.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack, and good morning, everyone. Consistent with our approach in the last call, I will use my time today to speak to the major drivers and events of the first quarter. This information is detailed in our consolidated report, which is posted to ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack, and good morning, everyone. Consistent with our approach in the last call, I will use my time today to speak to the major drivers and events of the first quarter. This information is detailed in our consolidated report, which is posted to our website, and we would be happy to address any specific questions in the Q&A or after the call. As Chuck said, this morning we reported strong 2015 first quarter operating earnings of $0.62 per share, which compares to $0.39 per share in the first quarter of 2014. On a GAAP basis, basic and diluted earnings for the first quarter of 2015 were $0.53 per share compared to many 2014 first quarter basic earnings of $0.50 per share or $0.49 per share on a diluted basis. We are off to a good start for the year. First quarter 2015 operating earnings were fairly clean and simple. As expected, we benefited from improvements in our competitive business as well as increased transmission revenue, which were partially offset by a higher effective income tax rate in our corporate segment. From the standpoint of our first quarter guidance, we came in above the range we provided, largely due to the impact on our distribution business of extremely cold weather in late February and March. Compared to the normal weather that we include our guidance, first quarter wires revenue benefited by $0.06 per share as a result of heating-degree days that were 21% above-normal during the period. This was offset by about $0.03 per share related to weather impacts in our business. First quarter operating earnings also benefited by a net $0.03 per share compared to guidance, primarily as a result, of the New Jersey storm amortization delay and incremental revenue from our TrAILCo transmission interest. Overall, distribution deliveries increased slightly compared to last year, reflecting the weather as well as modest growth in our customer base offset by the impact of lower average customer use associated with energy efficiency. Residential sales were flat compared to the first quarter of 2014, but down 1.7% on weather-adjusted basis or both actual and weather-adjusted commercial sales increased slightly. Industrial sales were also up slightly, marking the seventh consecutive quarter of growth in that sector. While soft natural gas prices are deterring some new entrants into the shale gas field, our conservative estimates continue support more than 1,000 megawatts of new load from businesses through 2019. The shale slowdown contributed to softer first quarter demand from the steel sector; however, most of the other key sectors in our region remains solid. 
In our transmission business, first quarter operating earnings were $0.17 per share, reflecting incremental rate-based growth at both ATSI and forward-looking rates at ATSI beginning January 1, this year, partially offset by higher depreciation, taxes and interest expense. As Chuck described, our competitive business was able to more effectively navigate this year's extreme weather conditions, due to the changes we began putting in place during the second quarter of last year. Our 2015 first quarter operating results in this business reflect the benefits of this repositioning and improved plant availability as well as higher capacity revenues. For the 2015, our committed sales currently are about 70 million megawatt-hours essentially having sold everything we anticipated on a retail and forward wholesale basis, with over 8 million megawatt-hours available for spot wholesale sales over the remainder of the year. For 2015, we are also reducing our generation production estimate from about 79 million megawatt-hours down to about 72 million megawatt-hours due to the economic and market conditions we experienced during the first quarter in a market price outlook for the balance of 2015. If it is more economic for us to purchase power from market to serve load when needed, we will do so, but we have the benefit of our own generating resources if and when we need to call on them. Ultimately, market conditions will determine how much we generate from the fleet and how much purchase. Essentially, we will source the power to meet our retail load obligations as economically as possible. For 2016, approximately 70% of our projected sales are committed. Based on our results for the first quarter, we are reaffirming our 2015 adjusted EBITDA range for the competitive business of $875 million to $950 million, as well as our 2016 adjusted EBITDA range of $750 million to $850 million. Consistent with the guidance we provided earlier this year, corporate consolidated effective tax rate was 38.8% in the first quarter of 2015, compared to 30.3% in the first quarter of 2014. This change drove an $0.08 per share decrease in the corporate segment compared to last year and reflects the elimination of certain future tax liabilities associated with basis differences in the first quarter of 2014. 
This year is off to a solid start and we are executing our plans to improve our company's fundamentals and drive long-term shareholder value through customer-focused growth. As Chuck said, we are reaffirming our 2015 guidance range of $2.40 to $2.70 per share and are also providing a second quarter operating earnings range of $0.42 to $0.50 per share. With that, I'd like to open the call for your questions.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015

componenttext: Just following up on the cost-cutting plan -- thanks for your additional detail, but could we maybe dig a little bit more into where you're seeing those buckets of savings, may be between regulated, nonregulated, and kind of the scaling of these opportunities as you get further into the plan?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Dan, let me say it this way. I think I said in my remarks that we are going to be focused primarily on the generation business. We are going to look at everything. The reason that the scope said about $2.5 billion is because there are certain bucket
componenttext: Well, Dan, let me say it this way. I think I said in my remarks that we are going to be focused primarily on the generation business. We are going to look at everything. The reason that the scope said about $2.5 billion is because there are certain buckets of expenditures that would be counterproductive to our regulated growth strategy to go and try to address those, for example, our transmission expansion plans. So we are focusing primarily on generation. We are very cognizant of the fact that we don't want to do anything to take the growth strategy in our company off-track.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: And if you were to think about what that does inflation, or these -- What is the underlying O&M inflation going to be your net of these savings? Is that the right way to think about kind of forward?
componenttext: And if you were to think about what that does inflation, or these -- What is the underlying O&M inflation going to be your net of these savings? Is that the right way to think about kind of forward?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure. I understand your question.
componenttext: I'm not sure. I understand your question.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess, are these savings are going to be net reduction in O&M year-by-year, or is there a level of inflation that will eat up some of the savings -- '16, '17, '18 numbers?
componenttext: So I guess, are these savings are going to be net reduction in O&M year-by-year, or is there a level of inflation that will eat up some of the savings -- '16, '17, '18 numbers?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that initially this is going to be a step down in our cost structure. And like any business over time, then there are incremental adjustments that are made as we offer our employee wage increases as they are in things that go on in the econo
componenttext: Well, I think that initially this is going to be a step down in our cost structure. And like any business over time, then there are incremental adjustments that are made as we offer our employee wage increases as they are in things that go on in the economy. But one to keep in mind is, we have not included staffing in this phase of what we're doing. We will have annually about 1,000 employer each year. And going forward, we expect to make adjustments in the structure of our organization, such that those attritions should pretty much offset any inflationary pressures that are on where we are at when this project is done.

componenttext: Okay. I guess, while the topic was in the Supreme Court; hopefully, addressing 745 case on Monday. Can you just talk about what the process would be from a legal perspective for you guys if the Supreme Court takes the case or if they choose not to take the case?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Leila can.
componenttext: Leila can.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if they chose to take the case, then I would expect court to continue to address capacity performance, they have already rejected as premature PJM's attempt to modify the DR process. So it would continue as a supply product as it has in the past
componenttext: Okay. So if they chose to take the case, then I would expect court to continue to address capacity performance, they have already rejected as premature PJM's attempt to modify the DR process. So it would continue as a supply product as it has in the past and wait for some final determination from the Supreme Court determination with regard to demand response. If they decide not to take the case, I can speak to what should happen. In what should happen, demand response should come out of the capacity auction of the supply product. From our standpoint, we believe there is a place for demand response. We believe that that is on the side of state implementation plan, and we think going forward that would be a useful product and can still be maintained. With regard to how PJM views it, we know they view that as a valuable product. So I would imagine at a practical level, PJM will be seeking to somehow demand response within the capacity auction.

componenttext: So we still have our case out there that had challenged the prior residual auction. FERC has put back or has not addressed that. So with regard to that auction, anyway there is some question as to what would happen and whether it would be appropriate in our view to take demand out, take out the price the associated with the demand response and not rerun the auction, but just remove the effects of demand response.

componenttextpreview: With the cost cut commentary today, does that preclude now the need to issue equity for the foreseeable future, particularly given some of the FFO to debt metrics and some of the credit rating agencies are looking at?
componenttext: With the cost cut commentary today, does that preclude now the need to issue equity for the foreseeable future, particularly given some of the FFO to debt metrics and some of the credit rating agencies are looking at?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, here is what I've said on that topic. All along, I believe that it's incumbent on us to find a way to fundamentally operate our company in a way to way we don't have to use equity to strengthen our balance sheet. I think these cost-cutting initiativ
componenttext: Well, here is what I've said on that topic. All along, I believe that it's incumbent on us to find a way to fundamentally operate our company in a way to way we don't have to use equity to strengthen our balance sheet. I think these cost-cutting initiatives will get us to a place where we can be successful in not having to do that. Then going forward, I think we are equity should be used is where its is intended to be used in our business, and that is to generate growth in our business. So we may look at equity down the road to use for growth there in additional transmission investment or potentially even investment inside the distribution companies. But I believe we can get ourselves to a position where the cost-cutting puts us at the bottom end of the range that we need to be in from the credit metrics perspective and then these cost over time will continue to improve the balance sheet.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we need to see first where FERC and PJM land in terms of a capacity performance, product being in the auction. Then we need to sit down and take a look at how are we going to approach that auction from a bidding strategy. And then we need to see w
componenttext: I think we need to see first where FERC and PJM land in terms of a capacity performance, product being in the auction. Then we need to sit down and take a look at how are we going to approach that auction from a bidding strategy. And then we need to see what units clear and at what price stay clear? And then from there, we will decide what the appropriate investment in our units to make sure that they are available with the need to be. So there are lot of unanswered questions, and there is a lot of competitive implications around how we are going to approach this, So I prefer not to get into the details. So -- but we understand that there is teh potential that we may want to do some additional investment in our fleet, but that all depends on where these roles shakeout and where the market ultimately clears at.

componenttext: Well, I wouldn't say we've been flirting with it. We have a major hurdle we had to get through, which is a base rate case for all of those companies, which we are now through. And now what I've done is, I've asked our energy delivery team to look at what investments makes sense for customers inside those operating companies. And I have pretty consistently said, I'm going to go invest money where it make sense for customers. So until we see exactly company-by-company what the needs are to drive reliability improvement and improve customer service, I can't answer that. I think I've said that we could spend up to about $440 million in Pennsylvania and stay under the 5% cap. I don't see us going anywhere near that number in the first disc filing that we would make if we make one. But we are putting that business case together right now.

componenttext: Okay, great. Thanks for clarity. Then also on, I think Dan's question on FERC. headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think you misunderstood what I said. What FERC has done, PJM came to FERC and asked to consider the demand side of the equation and FERC told them that they're premature on that. So if the Supreme Court take of the case, that chance exist that deman
componenttext: No, I think you misunderstood what I said. What FERC has done, PJM came to FERC and asked to consider the demand side of the equation and FERC told them that they're premature on that. So if the Supreme Court take of the case, that chance exist that demand response might still be under FERC jurisdiction. And I think that's what FERC was looking out. So right now the way, I think play out is, demand response would be in the BRA auction, when it's held, presumably in the middle of August, and would be a supply-side item as it has been in the past.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: So back to last year when we held the BRA, and we filed the complaint with FERC, what we suggested was if demand response is not under FERC jurisdiction, than what the remedy it should be just to remove demand response from the supply side, and then you c
componenttext: So back to last year when we held the BRA, and we filed the complaint with FERC, what we suggested was if demand response is not under FERC jurisdiction, than what the remedy it should be just to remove demand response from the supply side, and then you can still stack up from how the auction was, what would've happened if the demand was not been taken but other generators would've been taken. So you take out price stock but you don't have -- nobody have to rebid everything back in the auction.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all I would say this, we are not afraid of any audit operations. I'm confident that when they do this review, they are going to see a JC P&L that is much different than the JC P&L they saw the last time that they did a review. The reason fo
componenttext: Well, first of all I would say this, we are not afraid of any audit operations. I'm confident that when they do this review, they are going to see a JC P&L that is much different than the JC P&L they saw the last time that they did a review. The reason for it is, as a result of the 2011 and 2012 storms, there were reliability issues that kind of crept in the rate case and there was no adequate mechanism within the rate case to deal with the reliability issues. So coming out of the rate case, this is a way that kind of put those reliability issues behind us and position us as I said, when we can now work with the to move forward together.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first of all, it so we filed for and as a result of the filing, what you're essentially seeing is the investments that we made in 2014 were made in a kind of an old formula rate. So for the first quarter this year, you're going to see the compound impa
componenttext: So first of all, it so we filed for and as a result of the filing, what you're essentially seeing is the investments that we made in 2014 were made in a kind of an old formula rate. So for the first quarter this year, you're going to see the compound impact of everything that we invested in '14, because the rate went into effect as well as the first quarter investments that we've made in those overall results. The difference between the 12.38% return and any other subsequent return that we might end up at is minimal and that's why we say we reserve this small amount, but we're moving forward with the 12.38% return until somebody tells us its a different return. And I believe there is a very strong case to be made, that if there is a different written, it should be different going forward from the point where there is a settlement not reverse.

Just what's your plan in terms of whether you maintain that short-term debt balance outstanding for a good while or whether you have the capability to pay it down or will you think about either it our or doing something else with it to reduce long-term interest rate exposure?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: We are waiting to see where we come out on these initiatives that Chuck talked about, Michael. We have some significant opportunity in the cash flow improvement project that Chuck talked about and then a couple of the other big items that we're still look
componenttext: We are waiting to see where we come out on these initiatives that Chuck talked about, Michael. We have some significant opportunity in the cash flow improvement project that Chuck talked about and then a couple of the other big items that we're still looking at the capacitive performance and the PPA. We don't have any plans right now to term any of that debt out. We will continue to look at it. The first quarter is a little bit unusual from cash flow output. We generally prepay our Pennsylvania gross receipts tax, that's about $170-some million. We have a pension contribution that we made in the first quarter, Ohio property taxes are due in the first and third quarter, and generally our plant payouts are in the first quarter. So it's a bit of an abnormal. I would expect that over the rest of the year, we will not see that balance to grow. In fact, we may reduce it somewhat, but we will continue to look at whether it makes sense to terminate it. I would prefer, as time goes on, to push that further down into the business units, have the debt closer to the asset. But I think got a wait to see where we come out on some of these initiatives before we make that final decision.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to encourage on this effort to improve of earnings. I wanted to ask a question regarding that. One of the distinct aspects of your operating earnings presentation, as I it and correct me if I'm wrong, is that unlike your GAAP earnings, where t
componenttext: I just want to encourage on this effort to improve of earnings. I wanted to ask a question regarding that. One of the distinct aspects of your operating earnings presentation, as I it and correct me if I'm wrong, is that unlike your GAAP earnings, where the difference between expected returns on pension assets and realized returns on pension assets is recognized every year in the fourth quarter, and operating earnings, there's actually no recognition of that difference. And I estimate over the last 5 years that difference of expected returns over actual returns on pension assets has been something like $570 million. This works out to an average of $115 million a year or $0.27 per share. So I was -- my question then is, are you thinking of ways in which you could perhaps reflect more accurately and operating earnings the outcome of your pension investments?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: We make that decision a number of years ago to record any changes in actuarial or assumptions on a mark-to-market basis. In our ongoing operating results, we have all of the service costs in there and then any changes in the actuarial assumptions. And the
componenttext: We make that decision a number of years ago to record any changes in actuarial or assumptions on a mark-to-market basis. In our ongoing operating results, we have all of the service costs in there and then any changes in the actuarial assumptions. And the biggest piece of that is, is generally the change in the discount rate, which has fallen over the last few years. So we have no intention of changing the way we report our pension in our operating earnings going forward. But we fully break that out and let you know what the discount rate is and the actual return on the asset.

componenttextpreview: Well, I want to let Donny take it. As I told you, our goal is to run the competitive business overall a little more conservatively, so that we can have predictable results, and that's what we're trying to achieve. And obviously, what I talked about is, th
componenttext: Well, I want to let Donny take it. As I told you, our goal is to run the competitive business overall a little more conservatively, so that we can have predictable results, and that's what we're trying to achieve. And obviously, what I talked about is, the fact that last year there was a vortex, this year in February, there was termed as Siberian express, which was actually more severe weather and a higher PJM peak load. And I think that, we were able to capitalize on some of that weather improvement that we get on the utility side by doing what I said, and that is operating our generating business much more conservatively. And part of that is, we're not going to dispatch units into a price that they don't make money. If he can avoid doing that. So Donny, you want to fill in any details.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve, I just say, we've had a long history of this kind of thing. If you recall back in 2009 timeframe when the market first collapsed, we took our plants offline, we took that workforce out of   out of the plants and moved into the regulated side o
componenttext: Yes, Steve, I just say, we've had a long history of this kind of thing. If you recall back in 2009 timeframe when the market first collapsed, we took our plants offline, we took that workforce out of   out of the plants and moved into the regulated side of business. Summer of 2012, we took the plant offline. We took it offline for about 3 or 4 months, and then ultimately brought it back online. What we have now that's different than what we've had in the past, is a lot more free board. When you have that open position into the spot market, you're able to take advantage of the market much more readily than what we've had in the past, because we have a cushion there from a risk perspective. So when you look back at this previous quarter, we had Mansfield plant completely offline for about a straight week when the price was below our margin cost.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood, that makes sense. And then, just touching on performance during the winter. It sounds like this winter you all had a much better operational performance. When we talked a little bit past about this, just curious, how can you -- can you talk ab
componenttext: Understood, that makes sense. And then, just touching on performance during the winter. It sounds like this winter you all had a much better operational performance. When we talked a little bit past about this, just curious, how can you -- can you talk about the changes you had year-over-year and how you physically manage the fleet for weather risk and how that positions you going forward?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the biggest difference between January of '14 and this year was we had a generator step-up transformer failure at Beaver Valley 1, and that is -- it was not our weather-related event, even though the temperature outside might have been 17 below 0. T
componenttext: Well, the biggest difference between January of '14 and this year was we had a generator step-up transformer failure at Beaver Valley 1, and that is -- it was not our weather-related event, even though the temperature outside might have been 17 below 0. The temperature inside that transformer is around 75 to 90 degrees C. So it was a random failure that just happened to occur at the worst time that it could possibly occur. So that was the biggest impact on 2014. Beyond that we took some steps to harden if you will, some of the equipment that is outdoors and subject to weather that our plants that could lead to a disruption in unit performance, but there wasn't a whole lot of significant work and expenditures necessary to do that. And I would just tell you that the teamwork between our commodity group and I our generation fleet was exceptional this winter, and that also led to the type of results that we were able to accomplish.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that was a last question. So we want to thank you, all, for your support. Obviously, I think we had a pretty good quarter, it was influenced by the weather, and I'm not going to take credit for the weather because we've got July and August coming, a
componenttext: Okay, that was a last question. So we want to thank you, all, for your support. Obviously, I think we had a pretty good quarter, it was influenced by the weather, and I'm not going to take credit for the weather because we've got July and August coming, and goes the other way, I'm not going to take the blame for the weather either. But it was a good start of the year. If you dig down below that, our operational performance was right on schedule with what we're trying to accomplish, and I know 1 quarter doesn't make a trend, but you have to start with 1 before you can get to 10 or 12. So that's our game plan and we thank you, all, for your support.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015

componenttext:
Greetings and welcome to the FirstEnergy Corp. First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I would like to now turn the conference over to your host, Meghan Beringer, Director of Investor Relations for FirstEnergy Corp. Thank you, Ms. Beringer, you may now begin.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kevin. Welcome to our First Quarter Earnings Call. Today, we will make various forward-looking statements regarding revenues, earnings, performance, strategies and prospects. These statements are based on current expectations and are subject to
componenttext:
Thanks, Kevin. Welcome to our First Quarter Earnings Call. 
Today, we will make various forward-looking statements regarding revenues, earnings, performance, strategies and prospects. These statements are based on current expectations and are subject to risk and uncertainties. Factors that could cause actual results or outcomes to differ materially from those indicated by such statements can be found on the Investors section of our website under the Earnings Information link and in our SEC filings. 
We will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures are also available on our website. 
Participating in today's call are Chuck Jones, President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Pearson, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Leila Vespoli, Executive Vice President, Markets and Chief Legal Officer; Donny Schneider, President of FirstEnergy Solutions; Jason Petrik, our Corporate Assistant Controller; Steve Staub, Vice President and Treasurer; and Irene Prezelj, Vice President, Investor Relations. Now I will turn the call over to Chuck Jones.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Meghan, and good morning, everyone. It's a pleasure to speak with you today. We had a good quarter and we're off to a great start for the year. Since our last call in February, we have continued our work to position FirstEnergy for solid, predicta
componenttext:
Thanks, Meghan, and good morning, everyone. It's a pleasure to speak with you today. We had a good quarter and we're off to a great start for the year. Since our last call in February, we have continued our work to position FirstEnergy for solid, predictable and customer service driven regulated growth. 
This morning, we will talk about our progress on those strategies. We will discuss other key initiatives, including an important effort that is underway to reduce our cost structure and drive improvements to our balance sheet. And of course, we will review our first quarter financial results and operational performance. 
Similar to our last call, we intend to keep these prepared remarks brief to allow ample time for your questions before the end of the hour. 
Our first quarter operating earnings of $0.62 per share are slightly above the top end of our guidance range and give us a solid foundation to start of the year. We benefited from the growth in our Transmission business and solid distribution performance that was assisted by second year of unusually cold weather. Our year-over-year results also reflect the actions we began taking in the second quarter of 2014 to reposition the retail sales portfolio in our competitive business. 
For the past year, we have talked about the extreme weather events of 2014's first quarter and the impact those conditions had on our competitive business and our strategy. The first quarter of 2015 was even colder, with heating-degree days totaling 21% above normal and 2% higher than 2014. The PJM market also set a new winter peak of 144,000 megawatts, exceeding the previous winter peak which was set in January of 2014. 
In our competitive business, however, the difference in our results between this winter and last is striking. This improvement speaks to the benefit of our more conservative strategy, which includes 3 major components. First, selling no more than we produce in order to maintain an open position of at least 10 million to 20 million megawatt-hours annually to protect against extreme weather, unplanned outages or a combination of both. As a result of our actions to strategically reduce load obligations, our 2015 retail and polar obligations are expected to be about 68 million megawatt-hours compared to 99 million megawatt-hours in 2014. 
Second, reducing exposure to weather-sensitive load. From January of 2014 through March of 2015, our overall retail obligations are down nearly 35% on an annualized basis, with much of that coming from serving fewer of the most weather-sensitive residential and small commercial customers. 
And finally, a more rigorous commitment to economically dispatching our units. This strategy, together with improved plant operations, helped to mitigate the potential downside from this year's severe first quarter weather and demand conditions even though our region experienced 4 more below 0 days this February than last January. 
As contracts continue to roll off, we expect a further decrease in our annualized retail load obligation through the end of this year, and much of the decline will be associated with the most weather-sensitive load. 
As I have mentioned to many of you previously, we recognize that reducing risk in the business also means that we're likely giving up some earnings potential. But as we have said, our objective is to make the competitive business more stable as we focus our efforts on growth in the regulated businesses. In that regard, the last few months have been a busy, busy period for our Energizing the Future transmission investment program. 
We are nearing completion of projects that are designed to maintain service reliability in the wake of plant deactivations in the Northern Ohio. Those plants ceased operations for good on April 15. These projects included the Bruce Mansfield-Glenwillow project, a $195 million, 345 kilovolt transmission line extending 119 miles from Western Pennsylvania to Suburban Cleveland scheduled to go in service by June 1.
In addition, we are preparing to energize new 345-kilovolt substations and associated transmission upgrades in Wood, Trumbull and Stark counties, which are designed to maintain service rollout reliability in Northern Ohio after the plants are closed. We also continued our work to strengthen the grid to help protect it from storms and make network and physical security upgrades. 
Finally, we are on track with our planned investments on projects that will support the midstream gas operations with about $365 million in the pipeline through 2019.
On the regulatory front, our rate cases in New Jersey and Pennsylvania have concluded. In Pennsylvania, we were pleased that the PUC accepted our rate plan settlements for each of our 4 utilities in the state. The new rates, which will be effective on Sunday, will help our operating companies continue to enhance reliability and service to our Pennsylvania customers. We are looking at further options for customer-focused investments going forward, including the option to possibly request a distribution system improvement charge to recover the cost of those investments. 
In New Jersey, we received recovery of approximately $580 million in cost incurred by JCP&L for the 2012 storms, and we are glad to have the long process and uncertainty behind us. Now we look forward to working with the BPU as we set a course for our future infrastructure and reliability investments at JCP&L. 
We have had a good and productive start to the year and we are making solid progress toward our long-term goals. Looking forward, there are still 3 major initiatives underway that will ultimately help shape our company and our strategies going forward. 
First, in Ohio, the hearing on our electric security plan has been delayed by 60 days and is scheduled to begin on June 15. As you know, in its recent decisions on the AEP and Duke cases, the PUCO ruled that stability riders related to purchase power agreements similar to our proposal are legal in Ohio. This was an extremely significant outcome. We believe that our filing includes a robust case for how our proposal benefits utility customers and supports economic development in the state. On May 4, we expect to file supplemental testimony to further demonstrate how our plan meets the factors outlined in the AEP and Duke cases. 
While we are comfortable with the new schedule set by the PUCO, this schedule will affect the timing of our analyst meeting which we had hoped to have this summer. We believe that it makes sense to host this meeting after we receive a decision in Ohio, which pushes us to sometime late this year.
The second open matter that could have a significant impact on our business is the PJM capacity performance proposal. PJM has addressed FERC's questions into the structure of the product. Pending its final decision, FERC granted PJM's requested waiver to delay the May capacity auction to no later than the week of August 10. We appreciate the care and long-term perspective that FERC is taking in its review of this important mechanism and expect that both PJM and FERC are interested in reaching a resolution as soon as possible. In both of these matters, we look forward to a final outcome that produces better clarity for our company and produces benefits for electric consumers in our region. 
On a related item, as you know, we had delayed our decision to construct a new dewatering facility for our 2,400 megawatt Bruce Mansfield plant in Pennsylvania while we evaluated the plants future, particularly with respect to the results of the next capacity auction. We will continue to monitor market conditions, but given the current environment, including the auction delay, we think it makes sense to move forward with some early aspects of this project. This work is designed to preserve our ability to continue operations of the plant after December 31, 2016. All costs associated with this project are in our current business plan. 
We of course intend to remain sharply focused on those things we can control, including our own spending on goods and services, operating expenses and other corporate spending as well as capital expenditures. 
Last month, we launched a cash flow improvement project intending to capture both immediate and long-term savings opportunities that are meaningful and sustainable. A team led by FES President Donny Schneider is working to identify savings and process improvements across the company with a particular emphasis on our generation business. The team is focused on expense reductions, capital expenditures and inventory. We're also working with an outside consultant to examine the significant savings potential in our supply chain. 
With more than $2.5 billion in annual spending in the project scope, we believe that significant cost savings opportunities are available while continuing to successfully serve the needs of our organization, customers and employees. I will note that workforce and benefit reductions are not included in the scope of the project. 
In all, we are targeting $50 million in savings this year and an additional $150 million in 2016, reaching a run rate of $200 million by 2017. We expect that the savings will be split about evenly between O&M expenses and capital expenditures and help us create sustainable levels for the future. By appropriately addressing our cost structure, we can help direct our future and move FirstEnergy to a point that our fundamental operations make the company stronger while improving the balance sheet over time. 
We're off to a solid start in 2015. Our early financial results, together with our progress on our strategic initiatives, are building a solid foundation for the year and for the future of our company. These results and our outlook for the remainder of the year continue to support 2015 operating guidance in the range of $2.40 to $2.70 per share. Consistent with the leadership philosophy I've shared with many of you, I would like to narrow the gap between our GAAP and non-GAAP results. While some differences are expected, we are diligently focused on earnings quality. 
Now we will turn the call over to Jim for a brief review of our first quarter financial results, then we'll open the call to your questions.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. Consistent with our approach in the last call, I will use my time today to speak to the major drivers and events of the first quarter. This information is detailed in our consolidated report which is posted to ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. Consistent with our approach in the last call, I will use my time today to speak to the major drivers and events of the first quarter. This information is detailed in our consolidated report which is posted to our website. And we would be happy to address any specific questions in the Q&A or after the call. 
As Chuck said, this morning, we reported strong 2015 first quarter operating earnings of $0.62 per share, which compares to $0.39 per share in the first quarter of 2014. On a GAAP basis, basic and diluted earnings for the first quarter of 2015 were $0.53 per share compared to 2014 first quarter basic earnings of $0.50 per share or $0.49 per share on a diluted basis. 
We're off to a good start for the year. First quarter of 2015 operating earnings were fairly clean and simple. As expected, we benefited from improvements in our competitive business as well as increased transmission revenue which were partially offset by a higher effective income tax rate in our corporate segment. 
From the standpoint of our first quarter guidance, we came in above the range we've provided largely due to the impact on our distribution business of extremely cold weather in late February and March. Compared to the normal weather that we include our guidance, first quarter wires revenue benefited by $0.06 per share as a result of heating-degree days that were 21% above normal during the period. This was offset by about $0.03 per share related to weather impacts at our competitive business. First quarter operating earnings also benefited by a net $0.03 per share compared to guidance, primarily as a result of the New Jersey storm amortization delay and incremental revenue from our TrAIL transmission investments. 
Overall, distribution deliveries increased slightly compared to last year, reflecting the weather as well as modest growth in our customer base, offset by the impact of lower average customer use associated with energy efficiency. 
Residential sales were flat compared to the first quarter of 2014, but down 1.7% on a weather-adjusted basis, while or both actual and weather-adjusted commercial sales increased slightly. Industrial sales were also up slightly, marking the seventh consecutive quarter of growth in that sector. 
While soft natural gas prices are deterring some new entrants into the shale gas fields, our conservative estimates continue to support more than 1,000 megawatts of new load from midstream businesses through 2019. The shale slowdown contributed to softer first quarter demand from the steel sector, however, most of the other key sectors in our region remained solid. 
In our transmission business, first quarter operating earnings were $0.17 per share, reflecting incremental rate-based growth at both ATSI and TrAIL and forward-looking rates at ATSI beginning January 1 this year, partially offset by higher depreciation, taxes and interest expense. As Chuck described, our competitive business was able to more effectively navigate this year's extreme weather conditions due to the changes we began putting in place during the second quarter of last year. 
Our 2015 first quarter operating results in this business reflect the benefits of this repositioning and improved plant availability as well as higher capacity revenues. For 2015, our committed sales currently are about 70 million megawatt-hours, essentially having sold everything we anticipated on a retail and forward-wholesale basis, with over 8 million megawatt-hours available for spot wholesale sales over the remainder of the year. 
For 2015, we are also reducing our generation production estimate from about 79 million megawatt-hours down to about 72 million megawatt-hours due to the economic and market conditions we experienced during the first quarter and a market price outlook for the balance of 2015. If it is more economic for us to purchase power from the market to serve load when needed, we will do so, but we have the benefit of our own generating resources if and when we need to call on them. Ultimately, market conditions will determine how much we generate from the fleet and how much we purchase. Essentially, we will source the power to meet our retail load obligations as economically as possible. For 2016, approximately 70% of our projected sales are committed. 
Based on our results for the first quarter, we are reaffirming our 2015 adjusted EBITDA range for the competitive business of $875 million to $950 million, as well as our 2016 adjusted EBITDA range of $750 million to $850 million. 
Consistent with the guidance we provided earlier this year, the corporate consolidated effective tax rate was 38.8% in the first quarter of 2015 compared to 30.3% in the first quarter of 2014. This change drove an $0.08 per share decrease in the corporate segment compared to last year and reflects the elimination of certain future tax liabilities associated with basis differences in the first quarter of 2014. 
This year is off to a solid start, and we are executing our plans to improve our company's fundamentals and drive long-term shareholder value through customer-focused regulated growth. As Chuck said, we are reaffirming our 2015 guidance range of $2.40 to $2.70 per share and are also providing a second quarter operating earnings range of $0.42 to $0.50 per share. 
With that, I'd like to open the call for your questions.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Dan, let me say it this way. I think I said in my remarks that we're going to be focused primarily on the generation business. We're going to look at everything. The reason that the scope is set at about $2.5 billion is because there are certain buc
componenttext: Well, Dan, let me say it this way. I think I said in my remarks that we're going to be focused primarily on the generation business. We're going to look at everything. The reason that the scope is set at about $2.5 billion is because there are certain buckets of expenditures that it would be counterproductive to our regulated growth strategy to go and try to address those, for example, our transmission expansion plan. So we are focusing primarily on generation. We're very cognizant of the fact that we don't want to do anything to take the growth strategy in our regulated companies off track.

componenttext: Okay. So I guess if you think about -- so are these savings going to be net reductions in O&M year-by-year? Or is there a level of inflation that will eat up some of the savings? For thinking about our '16, '17, '18 numbers?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that initially, this is going to be a step down in our cost structure. And like any business over time, then there are incremental adjustments that are made, as we offer our employee wage increases, as there are inflationary things that go o
componenttext: Well, I think that initially, this is going to be a step down in our cost structure. And like any business over time, then there are incremental adjustments that are made, as we offer our employee wage increases, as there are inflationary things that go on in the economy. But one to keep in mind is we have not included staffing in this phase of what we're doing. We will have annually about 1,000 employee attritions each year. And going forward, we expect to make adjustments in the structure of our organization such that those attritions should pretty much offset any inflationary pressures that are on where we're at when this project's done.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess one other topic with the Supreme Court hopefully addressing the 745 case on Monday. Can you just talk about what the process would be from a legal perspective for you guys if the Supreme Court takes the case? Or if they choose not to tak
componenttext: Okay. And I guess one other topic with the Supreme Court hopefully addressing the 745 case on Monday. Can you just talk about what the process would be from a legal perspective for you guys if the Supreme Court takes the case? Or if they choose not to take the case?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Leila can.
componenttext: Leila can.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if they choose to take the case, then I would expect FERC to continue to address capacity performance. They've already rejected as premature PJM's attempt to modify the DR process. So it would continue as a supply product, as it has in the past,
componenttext: Okay. So if they choose to take the case, then I would expect FERC to continue to address capacity performance. They've already rejected as premature PJM's attempt to modify the DR process. So it would continue as a supply product, as it has in the past, and wait for some final determination from the Supreme Court, substinate [ph] determination with regard to demand response. If they decide not to take the case, I can speak to what, in theory, should happen. In theory, what should happen, demand response should come out of the capacity auction as a supply product. From our standpoint, we believe there is a place for demand response. We believe that, that is on the side of state implementation plans. And we think going forward, that would be a useful product and can still be maintained. With regard to how PJM views it, we know they view that as a very valuable product. So I would imagine at a practical level, PJM will be seeking to somehow re-include demand response within the capacity auction.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is it going to be practical to -- if they don't take that case, and they have to go this removal of DR. A, is it practical that it can be reasonably well addressed for this upcoming auction? And then what is your view on whether retroactively, prior aucti
componenttext: Is it going to be practical to -- if they don't take that case, and they have to go this removal of DR. A, is it practical that it can be reasonably well addressed for this upcoming auction? And then what is your view on whether retroactively, prior auctions need to be adjusted?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we still have our case out there that had challenged the prior base residual auction. FERC has been -- has put it on the back burner, has not addressed that. I would anticipate they're going to need to do something with regard to that, too. So with reg
componenttext: So we still have our case out there that had challenged the prior base residual auction. FERC has been -- has put it on the back burner, has not addressed that. I would anticipate they're going to need to do something with regard to that, too. So with regard to that auction anyway, there is some question as to what would happen and whether it would be appropriate in our view to take demand response out, take out the price suppression effects associated with demand response and not rerun the auction, but just remove the effects of demand response.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question today is coming from Brian Chin from Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Brian Chin from Merrill Lynch.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: With the cost cut commentary today, does that preclude now the need to issue equity for the foreseeable future, particularly given some of the FFO-to-debt metrics that some of the credit rating agencies are looking at?
componenttext: With the cost cut commentary today, does that preclude now the need to issue equity for the foreseeable future, particularly given some of the FFO-to-debt metrics that some of the credit rating agencies are looking at?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, here's what I've said on that topic. All along, I believe that it's incumbent on us to find a way to fundamentally operate our company in a way to where we don't have to use equity to strengthen our balance sheet. I think these cost-cutting initiati
componenttext: Well, here's what I've said on that topic. All along, I believe that it's incumbent on us to find a way to fundamentally operate our company in a way to where we don't have to use equity to strengthen our balance sheet. I think these cost-cutting initiatives will get us to a place where we can be successful in not having to do that. Then going forward, I think where equity should be used is where it's intended to be used in our business, and that is to generate growth in our business. So we may look at equity down the road to use for growth either in additional transmission investment or potentially even investment inside the distribution companies. But I believe we can get ourselves to a position where the cost cutting puts us at the bottom end of the range that we need to be in from a credit metrics perspective, and then these costs, over time, will continue to improve the balance sheet.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And also of the cost cuts and cash flow improvements, I think you said a $100 million of this was expenses and the remainder is cash flow improvements. Can you talk about, on the cash flow side, how much of that is just timing related as supposed t
componenttext: Great. And also of the cost cuts and cash flow improvements, I think you said a $100 million of this was expenses and the remainder is cash flow improvements. Can you talk about, on the cash flow side, how much of that is just timing related as supposed to permanent reductions? Or permanent improvements in cash flow, I should say.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think we can even talk about that right now. We just kicked this team off a few weeks back. We -- we're in the early stages of it. I think when we get to this point at the end of the second quarter, I think I'll be in a good position to tell you m
componenttext: I don't think we can even talk about that right now. We just kicked this team off a few weeks back. We -- we're in the early stages of it. I think when we get to this point at the end of the second quarter, I think I'll be in a good position to tell you more concretely what we've identified and what the ongoing impact on our company is going to be.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then last point and then I'll jump back. The cost cuts that you've got, they are embedded in the current EBITDA guidance? I thought I heard you say that, but I just want to confirm.

So we will be supplementing our testimony in all those regards.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Steve, I think we need to see where we end up with this initiative, first and foremost, and where that leaves us in terms of free cash flow once that's done. But I would say my goal is to use equity for new growth on top of the growth that we've alr
componenttext: Well, Steve, I think we need to see where we end up with this initiative, first and foremost, and where that leaves us in terms of free cash flow once that's done. But I would say my goal is to use equity for new growth on top of the growth that we've already communicated to you.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015

componenttext: Okay, good. And then last question. Just in terms of the transmission, my recollection is that you were going to be reserving for kind of -- some kind of ROE adjustment in transmission. headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: So here's what I'd say on that. We have been approved for a forward-looking formula rate at 12.38%. We are doing what we believe is prudent to go forward, but I think we're approaching those negotiations in the settlement process from that perspective. An
componenttext: So here's what I'd say on that. We have been approved for a forward-looking formula rate at 12.38%. We are doing what we believe is prudent to go forward, but I think we're approaching those negotiations in the settlement process from that perspective. And for me to give you anything else, I think we're negotiating against ourselves at this point, and I'm not prepared to do that. So we'll see where this process unfolds. But I think FERC approved us at 12.38%, and we're going to negotiate from there.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015

componenttext: First question on JCP&L. I know that you have the rate case resolved. Obviously, it was off of a 2011 test year, so you're not getting up to that authorized ROE. How soon could you refile to try to get the lag reduced between the authorized and the earned?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Neel. Actually, from the rate order, we are required to file a rate case by April of 2017. But as we always do, we continue to look at that. And I might expect a filing even sooner than that timeframe.
componenttext: Neel. Actually, from the rate order, we are required to file a rate case by April of 2017. But as we always do, we continue to look at that. And I might expect a filing even sooner than that timeframe.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: But one of the things we want to do here is we haven't really been able to sit down and talk with the BPU commissioners for almost 3 years now. And the President and I have talked, and we're going to get together and talk about the future of JCP&L togethe
componenttext: But one of the things we want to do here is we haven't really been able to sit down and talk with the BPU commissioners for almost 3 years now. And the President and I have talked, and we're going to get together and talk about the future of JCP&L together before we get to a point where then we can't talk again. So that's the game plan.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then Jim, I wanted to go back to your comments about possibly reducing the amount of terawatt hours that comes out of fleet in 2015. And I'm not sure if it was 2016 as well. In 2015, would it be a margin benefit just because you're purchasing p
componenttext: Great. And then Jim, I wanted to go back to your comments about possibly reducing the amount of terawatt hours that comes out of fleet in 2015. And I'm not sure if it was 2016 as well. In 2015, would it be a margin benefit just because you're purchasing power at a cheaper cost than generating? Or are the actual terawatt hours coming down for stuff that you haven't hedged? And does that also affect 2016 as well?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Neel, what we're looking at is it would be margin benefit because we would be looking at buying power cheaper than what we would produce it at.
componenttext: Neel, what we're looking at is it would be margin benefit because we would be looking at buying power cheaper than what we would produce it at.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: So it would be for the hedged portion, I guess, in 2015.
componenttext: So it would be for the hedged portion, I guess, in 2015.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: What about 2016? Have you commented on terawatt hours generation for that?
componenttext: What about 2016? Have you commented on terawatt hours generation for that?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we have that broken out in the factbook, Neel. I don't have the exact number right off the top of my head, but yes, we would have it out there. But in 2016, we're going to look at running and dispatching the plants no differently than we are right no
componenttext: Yes, we have that broken out in the factbook, Neel. I don't have the exact number right off the top of my head, but yes, we would have it out there. But in 2016, we're going to look at running and dispatching the plants no differently than we are right now. If it's cheaper to buy it from the market, that's what we will do.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just generally speaking, as far as some investment for the supercriticals to be CPP compliant, is there any general color you can give us as to how your fleet is positioned going into the auction in hopefully August?
componenttext: Great. And then just generally speaking, as far as some investment for the supercriticals to be CPP compliant, is there any general color you can give us as to how your fleet is positioned going into the auction in hopefully August?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well I think we need to see first where FERC and PJM land in terms of a capacity performance product being in the auction. Then we need to sit down and take a look at how are we going to approach that auction from a bidding strategy. Then we need to see w
componenttext: Well I think we need to see first where FERC and PJM land in terms of a capacity performance product being in the auction. Then we need to sit down and take a look at how are we going to approach that auction from a bidding strategy. Then we need to see what units clear and at what price they clear. And then from there, we'll decide what the appropriate investment in our units is to make sure that they're available when they need to be. So there are lot of unanswered questions and there's a lot of competitive implications around how we're going to approach this, So I'd prefer not to get into the details. So -- but we understand that there is the potential that we may want to do some additional investment in our fleet. But that all depends on where these rules shake out and where the market ultimately clears at.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015

componenttext: Our next question today is coming from Julien Dumoulin-Smith, UBS.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
