componenttext: In your initial remarks, you had mentioned one of the contributors to 1Q performance was -- I think it was more rigorous economic dispatch of the generation units. I wonder if you could you just expand in terms of how you approached it this year versus prior periods.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, why don't I let Donny take it. But as I've told you, our goal is to run the competitive business overall a little more conservatively so that we can have predictable results. And that's what we're trying to achieve. And obviously, what I talked abou
componenttext: Well, why don't I let Donny take it. But as I've told you, our goal is to run the competitive business overall a little more conservatively so that we can have predictable results. And that's what we're trying to achieve. And obviously, what I talked about is the fact that last year, there was a polar vortex. This year in February, there was what they termed as Siberian express, which was actually more severe weather and a higher PJM peak load. And I think that we were able to capitalize on some of that weather improvement that we get on the utility side by doing what I said, and that is operating our generating business much more conservatively. And part of that is we're not going to dispatch units into a price that they don't make money if we can avoid doing that. So Donny, you want to fill in any details? Or.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Stephen, I'd just say, we've had a long history of this kind of thing. If you recall back in 2009 timeframe when the market first collapsed, we took our Lake plants offline, we took that workforce out of Lake plants, moved them into the regulated sid
componenttext: Yes, Stephen, I'd just say, we've had a long history of this kind of thing. If you recall back in 2009 timeframe when the market first collapsed, we took our Lake plants offline, we took that workforce out of Lake plants, moved them into the regulated side of business. Summer of 2012, we took the Sammis plant offline, took it offline for about 3 or 4 months, and then ultimately brought it back online. What we have now that's different than what we've had in the past is a lot more free board. When you have that open position into the spot market, you're able to take advantage of the market much more readily than what we've had in the past because we have a cushion there from a risk perspective. So when you look back at this previous quarter, we had our Mansfield plant completely offline for about a straight week when the price was below our marginal cost.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Understood, that makes sense. And then just touching on performance during the winter. It sounds like this winter, you all had much better operational performance. And we talked a little bit in the past about this, but just curious, how can you -- c
componenttext: Okay. Understood, that makes sense. And then just touching on performance during the winter. It sounds like this winter, you all had much better operational performance. And we talked a little bit in the past about this, but just curious, how can you -- can you talk about the sort of changes you've had year-over-year in how you physically manage the fleet for weather risk? And how that positions you going forward?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, May 01, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the biggest difference between January of '14 and this year was we had a generator step-up transformer failure at Beaver Valley 1. And that is -- it was not a weather-related event even though the temperature outside might have been 17 below 0. The
componenttext:
Well, the biggest difference between January of '14 and this year was we had a generator step-up transformer failure at Beaver Valley 1. And that is -- it was not a weather-related event even though the temperature outside might have been 17 below 0. The temperature inside that transformer is around 75 to 90 degrees C. So it was a random failure that just happened to occur at the worst time that it could possibly occur. So that was the biggest impact on 2014. Beyond that, we took some steps to harden, if you will, some of the equipment that is outdoors and subject to weather at our power plants that could lead to a disruption in unit performance. But there wasn't a whole lot of significant work and expenditures necessary to do that. And I will just tell you that the teamwork between our commodity group and our generation fleet was exceptional this winter. And that also led to the type of results that we were able to accomplish.
Okay, well, I think that was the last question. 
So we want to thank you, all, for your support. Obviously, I think we had a pretty good quarter. It was influenced by the weather and I'm not going to take credit for the weather because we've got July and August coming and if that goes the other way, I'm not going to take blame for the weather either. But it was a good start to the year. If you dig down below that, our operational performance was right on schedule with what we're trying to accomplish. And I know one quarter doesn't make a trend, but you have to start with 1 before you can get to 10 or 12. So that's our game plan and we thank you, all, for your support.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greetings and welcome to the FirstEnergy Corp. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference be recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Meghan Beringer, Director of Investor Relations
componenttext: Greetings and welcome to the FirstEnergy Corp. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference be recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Meghan Beringer, Director of Investor Relations for FirstEnergy. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brenda, and good morning. Welcome to FirstEnergy's second quarter earnings call. Today, we will make various forward-looking statements regarding revenues, earnings, performance, strategies and prospects. These statements are based on current expe
componenttext:
Thanks, Brenda, and good morning. Welcome to FirstEnergy's second quarter earnings call. Today, we will make various forward-looking statements regarding revenues, earnings, performance, strategies and prospects. These statements are based on current expectations and are subject to risks and uncertainties. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those indicated by such statements can be found on the Investors section of our website under the Earnings Information link and in our SEC filings. 
We will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures are also available on our website. Participating in today's call are Chuck Jones, President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Pearson, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Leila Vespoli, Executive Vice President, Markets and Chief Legal Officer; Donny Schneider, President of FirstEnergy Solutions; John Taylor, Vice President, Controller and Chief Accounting Officer; Steve Staab, Vice President and Treasurer; Vice President, Commodity Operations and Irene Prezelj, Vice President, Investor Relations. Now I will turn the call over to Chuck Jones.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Meghan. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. I'm pleased to have this opportunity to share an update on what has been a very busy and productive period for FirstEnergy. We are continuing to make steady progress on our strategic initia
componenttext:
Thanks, Meghan. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. I'm pleased to have this opportunity to share an update on what has been a very busy and productive period for FirstEnergy. We are continuing to make steady progress on our strategic initiatives. We're achieving closure on several of the industry issues that impact our company, and we reported very strong financial results for the second quarter. Our efforts to position FirstEnergy for stable, predictable and customer service-driven growth remain on track, and I'm optimistic about our future. 
During my remarks today, I will review a number of recent developments and give you a sense of what we are expecting for the rest of the year. Following my comments and Jim's review of our financial and operating results, we'll have plenty of time for your questions. 
Our operating earnings for the second quarter were $0.53 per share, which is $0.03 above the top of the range we provided in May. These results were higher -- these results were driven by higher earnings in our transmission business and the benefits of our more conservative strategy in a competitive business. We continue to make solid progress on our Energizing the Future transmission initiatives, which as you know is expected to be the primary driver of our growth for the next several years. 
During the second quarter, we completed the project designed to support service reliability following the plant deactivations in Northern Ohio, and we continue our work to upgrade and strengthen the grid in the ATSI region and support midstream gas operations. We remain on pace to invest $970 million in our transmission business during 2015 with about 60% of this investment already complete. This year, we have also put into place the framework to ensure more timely recovery for our transmission investments. In January, we moved to a forward-looking formula rate structure for ATSI and on July 20, we filed with FERC a settlement agreement that maintains ATSI's ROE at 12.38% for the first 6 months of this year. Under the settlement, which remains subject to FERC approval, the rate adjust to 11.06% for the second half of this year and into 10.3% beginning January 1, 2016 until at least January 1, 2018. The average ROE for the 3-year period would be 10.83%. We are pleased to reach the settlement as it reflects to current transmission ROE environment and allows us to move forward with our Energizing the Future transmission investment plan for customers while ensuring timely recovery for the company. We expect approval from for later this year. In June, we filed request for authorization to transfer transmission assets owned by Penelec and JCP&L into a new transmission affiliate called Mid-Atlantic Interstate Transmission or MAIT. These assets represent approximately $900 million in rate base as of the end of 2014. If approved by FERC, the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission and the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities, MAIT will operate similarly to our 2 new transmission subsidiaries, ATSI and TrAILCo. We expect the structure to facilitate investments that can improve service reliability for customers of our Eastern utility companies, similar to what we are doing for customers connected to our ATSI transmission system. We are seeking approval from FERC in 6 months and from the state commissions by mid-2016. Prior to closing the transaction, MAIT will file for new transmission rates with FERC. In May, I outlined 3 key initiatives that will shape our company going forward. These are the cash flow improvement project, PJM, capacity market reforms and our Ohio ESP. 
Let's start with the results from our cash flow improvement project. I'm pleased to report that we expect this project resulted cash flow improvements of $58 million in 2015, $155 million in 2016 and $240 million in 2017, exceeding the original targets for all 3 years. We launched this project in April with the goal of capturing both immediate and long-term savings that are meaningful and sustainable. We have completed a thorough analysis of savings and process improvements that do not compromise our ability to serve the needs of our organization, our customers and our employees. And we are now moving forward to implement these plans. These improvements come primarily from our competitive and corporate functions. The largest categories include reducing expenses and capital at our competitive fleet, particularly in our subcritical fossil units, reducing fossil fuel and fuel-related commodity expenses and taking advantage of attrition across the company and implementing a selective hiring program. There are also nearly 100 smaller items that collectively make a strong impact. About 65% of these savings are expected from operating expenses and 35% are from capital and nuclear fuel improvements over the 3-year period. 
On Page 170 of our FactBook, which was posted on our website last evening, we include more details on the cash flow initiative. We've already begun the implementation process. In fact, the majority of the fuel savings that we identified have already been locked in, and the new contract pricing will begin in September. We've also established a project management office to ensure we capture these savings and are fully committed to successfully executing this plan and establishing a new foundation for FirstEnergy going forward. We believe it will result in a stronger and more flexible company with improved balance sheet over time. 
Turning the capacity market reforms. During the quarter, FERC approved PJM's new capacity performance roles and as you know, FERC issued an order last week allowing demand response and energy efficiency resources into the transitional options. Importantly, the base residual auction remains on track and is still scheduled to begin August 10. The 2016, '17 and 2017, '18 were delayed slightly and are now scheduled to begin on August 26 and September 3 respectively. Before I move from generation, let's quickly touch on the Supreme Court decision regarding MATS. While the EPA regulations remain in effect pending further judicial proceedings before the DC Circuit Court, I want to be clear that FirstEnergy is not contemplating reopening any of the units representing 4,769 megawatts of generation that were closed due to cost of compliance with the MATS regulations. For our remaining fleet, we have already spent a significant portion of the $370 million in capital expenditures for equipment upgrades that were acquired under MATS, and many projects are complete or underway. In our competitive generation fleet, we identified a total cost of $178 million to comply with the regulations, of which $62 million had been spent through June 30 this year. At our regulated fleet, the cost estimate was $192 million with $105 million of that spent through June 30. 
I will also mention that we are moving forward all aspects of the construction of the new dewatering facility for our 2400-megawatt Bruce Mansfield Plant in Pennsylvania. While the plant is still pressured by current market conditions, we believe moving forward with construction is prudent to ensure that these megawatts remain available to serve customers in 2017 after our disposal rates that will then expire. As we have previously mentioned, all costs associated with this project are in our current capital plan. 
Finally, let's move to our Ohio and our electric security plan. Based on the current procedural schedules, staff testimony is due August 14 with hearings to begin at the end of the month. As you would expect, we remain very engaged in this process. We filed supplemental testimony in early May to further emphasize the factors that the Ohio Commission outlined in the ADP and Duke induced. It is telling that the public utilities that serve the majority of customers in the state agree conceptually on an appropriate transition plan toward a future that ensures safe, reliable, clean and affordable power for all Ohio customers from industrial facilities to homeowners. Given the plant's benefits including economic development support, we believe our filing meets the criteria outlined by the commission, and we remain optimistic that this plan will result in sound state energy policy for our customers. 
We had a solid first half. Since the start of the year, we made tremendous progress toward our goals of investing in customer-focused growth, supporting sound energy policy and strengthening our company from within, and we know there is still work to be done to position FirstEnergy for the future. At this point, we are reaffirming our 2015 operating earnings guidance range of $2.40 a share to $2.70 a share, with all 3 of our operating segments trending favorably versus their mid-points. We're comfortable guiding to the top of this range. We expect to refine guidance in the third quarter call once we have seen the full effects of the summer weather. Collectively, the cash flow improvement initiatives, upcoming capacity auction results and Ohio ESP decision will drive the near-term financial strategy of our company and give us a much clearer view of the next 3 years, including earnings and cash flow and a determination on additional equity, if any, to drive growth in our regulated businesses. In addition, we have already begun our robust annual planning process, which includes updating projections for all of our utilities, especially now that we have the 3 major rate cases behind us. This effort will help us further refine our distribution utility earnings profile going forward. Many of you have asked about the status of our analyst meeting. At this time, we still intend to hold it after the outcome of the Ohio ESP, which may push the meeting into early 2016. We look forward to providing you a comprehensive view of our future planning at that time. Now I will turn the call over to Jim for a brief review of our second quarter financial results.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. My prepared remarks will focus on the major drivers and events of the quarter. As you know, more details are available in the consolidated report that was posted to our website yesterday evening. And as always, w
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. My prepared remarks will focus on the major drivers and events of the quarter. As you know, more details are available in the consolidated report that was posted to our website yesterday evening. And as always, we welcome your questions either in the Q&A or following the call. Today, we reported strong second quarter 2015 operating earnings of $0.53 per share, which compares to $0.49 per share last year. On a GAAP basis, basic earnings were $0.44 per share for the second quarter of 2015. GAAP earnings were $0.16 per basic share during the same period last year. As Chuck mentioned, our operating earnings were above our targeted range for the quarter. 
Let's look at the results from each of our segments, starting with the distribution business. Residential sales decreased 0.7% overall compared to the second quarter of 2014, while commercial sales increased 1%. Adjusting for weather, residential deliveries were down 2.4%, and commercial sales were flat. We are examining the residential usage trend, which has been down over the last 4 quarters on a weather-adjusted basis. We believe this is attributable to energy efficiency as average customer usage has also declined quarter-over-quarter. In the industrial sector, sales decreased 1.1% in the quarter, ending a 7-quarter run of increased demand from the customer class, primarily due to lower usage from the steel industry. The current rate of shale growth continues to be impacted by soft natural gas prices. While we still see support from more than 1,000 megawatts of new load from midstream activity through 2019, our forecast reflects greater confidence in the 2015 and 2016 projects, which represents about half of that load growth. 
Turning to our transmission business. Second quarter operating earnings increased $0.06 to $0.21 per share as a result of revenue increases from higher rate base and ATSI and the forward-looking rate structure that began in January. In our competitive business, operating earnings increased $0.01 per share compared to the same period last year, reflecting higher commodity margin associated with high-capacity revenues, a modest increase in wholesale sales and lower contract sales. Additionally, operating cost decreased year-over-year largely due to improved plant performance. As we said last quarter, we have essentially sold everything we anticipated for 2015 on a retail and forward wholesale basis, with a reserve of 5 million-megawatt hours available for spot wholesale sales through the end of the year. For 2016, about 70% of our expected generation resources are committed, and we are currently about 40% committed for 2017. Based on our results for the first half of the year and the projected savings from the cash flow improvement initiative, we are reaffirming our 2015 adjusted EBITDA range for the competitive business of $875 million to $950 million and increasing our 2016 adjusted EBITDA range to $825 million to $925 million from $750 million to $850 million. It was another solid quarter for our company, and this is shaping up to be a good year. As Chuck said, we are reaffirming our operating earnings guidance, and the trends we see so far this year make us confident at the top end of that range at this point. We are committed to achieving the cash savings we have identified and to building long-term shareholder value through our customer-focused regulated growth strategy. Now with that, I'd like to open the call for questions.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chuck, thanks for the additional detail on the cash flow improvement slides. I guess, in the sense of being greedy, 2 questions. One, what do you see as opportunity going forward for those numbers grow as you credit it to the further end of the process of
componenttext: Chuck, thanks for the additional detail on the cash flow improvement slides. I guess, in the sense of being greedy, 2 questions. One, what do you see as opportunity going forward for those numbers grow as you credit it to the further end of the process of evaluation? And then, two, can you talk a little bit about how you would get such big fuel savings out of your suppliers. You seem to be in pretty financial dire straits at this point?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, tell you what, I'll take the first question, and then I'll hand the second part of it to Don answer. And on the first one, I do think there are some opportunities for us to add to this over time, particularly in the supply chain area. We set a 12-we
componenttext: Well, tell you what, I'll take the first question, and then I'll hand the second part of it to Don answer. And on the first one, I do think there are some opportunities for us to add to this over time, particularly in the supply chain area. We set a 12-week time frame to complete this study. We can operate at that speed, but our suppliers don't all necessarily operate at that speed. So we've got a number of items in the queue that we're still working on the try to get across the finish line. So I think there is some opportunity to improve these over time, and I'll let Don tackle your fuel question.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Chuck. So when you take a look at the V6 savings, as you noted, Dan, one of the most significant savings and initiative comes from the reduction in the fossil fuel cost. And that total savings is about $151 million. It kind of breaks out as f
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Chuck. So when you take a look at the V6 savings, as you noted, Dan, one of the most significant savings and initiative comes from the reduction in the fossil fuel cost. And that total savings is about $151 million. It kind of breaks out as follows: about half or $75 million of the savings is really a result of working with our coal suppliers to reduce rates. And then we got about $50 million associated with our refined coal process where we partnered with several third parties to produce a coal that reduces emissions. We have a contractual relationship where we pay for every ton [ph] of coal that's treated, and the third party receives a tax credit under Section 45 of the tax code. These projects are now in place at Mansfield through 2021, and we're in the final steps of negotiating for presence. The balance, which is about $25 million is driven from several smaller items including reagent and waste disposal cost that as Chuck said, these already under contract. So that's part of the breakdown of the savings and clearly, the coal suppliers are in tight market times as well as we are. We found opportunities to build on our relationships. We've got good relationships with the coal suppliers and the transportation suppliers. We meet with them twice a year to work through these market challenges. We try to find ways we can partner in a win-win kind of an approach. So we have -- we've been successful so far. We look forward to working with them in the future.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015

componenttext: I'll just follow on a second there because I know I'm getting at this question later. The savings we were able to achieve the fuel supply particularly related to the Bruce Mansfield Plant were a big factor in our decision to move forward with the dewatering facility, makes that plant more competitive starting September 1.

componenttext: Thanks, Chuck. Hi, Dan. I think the delay in the hearing was in response to the commission's desire to get additional data points with regard to what's happening with the EPA, but I think more precisely, what's happening with the capacity performance. I don't think that that should be the be-all end-all, I think those are data points. But I also think they are mindful of the fact that our current ESP in the middle of next year. So there's no a lot of additional delays that can be tolerated within the scheduled we need to meet. So I think we're in a good place right now with regards to the timing of it. We have hearings starting August 31. One thing I'd like to point out, it was after the last call, that we continue to be in negotiations. And since our last call, we were able to add add are not opposing party and design party. So I think what is a percent of the commission is a very robust settlement. Still -- I'm still very hopeful but we will be able to move forward in a very positive way. And as always, we continue to additional parties on board.

componenttext: The transition business seems to be doing well, and I think in the past, you mentioned that maybe about $1 billion is the maximum you can spend a year. Is that number still right? Or could you deploy additional capital beyond that $1 billion if the process goes well and the Pennsylvania Utilities are included in the transcos?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there are several factors. We've communicated their plants for the next several years, and they amount to about $1 billion a year. MAIT will provide additional opportunities there for successful in getting it done. Our transmission infrastru
componenttext: Well, I think there are several factors. We've communicated their plants for the next several years, and they amount to about $1 billion a year. MAIT will provide additional opportunities there for successful in getting it done. Our transmission infrastructure has aged, and we've talked about a few projects that could potentially go on for a long time at the rate of $1 billion a year. So I think at that point in time, we would look at it, but I think a determining factor is the ability to resource additional construction. There is a shortage of transmission alignment around the country, and that would be a factor in terms of expanding it to any significant amount, I think.

I think we need the PPAs. headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could comment on the appeals to the Supreme Court of Ohio of the AAP, PPA proposal whether that's relevant, whether you think that's relevant to your case at all and if you care to comment on whether you think the Supreme Court woul
componenttext: I was wondering if you could comment on the appeals to the Supreme Court of Ohio of the AAP, PPA proposal whether that's relevant, whether you think that's relevant to your case at all and if you care to comment on whether you think the Supreme Court would take your case?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gregg, this is Leila. I think right now that those appeals are premature. There is still after a hearing associated with that case. And in Ohio, I don't think how you get the Supreme Court to pick those up when absolutely hearing are pending. So we absolu
componenttext: Gregg, this is Leila. I think right now that those appeals are premature. There is still after a hearing associated with that case. And in Ohio, I don't think how you get the Supreme Court to pick those up when absolutely hearing are pending. So we absolutely expect those cases, those appeals to be dismissed. Doesn't mean they can't refile them a later date but again, I think they're premature. So I don't think there can have any effect on our case. And with regard to my risk conjecture, say forward somehow, things would be stayed in Ohio. If a case is going before the Ohio Supreme Court, the decision goes forward, commission decision goes forward and is not stayed unless a specific statutory provision is met. And in the that provision, the party that is requesting the state needs to provide an post bond. So that's a very high hurdle to assume within the context of these type of cases. So bottom line, no effect.

componenttext: Yes, I would say, Jonathan, for the second half of the year, you won't see the robust growth that we saw on the first quarter. We were up $0.11 year-over-year for the second quarter -- or for the second half of the year, you're going to have a much higher rate base that you're been a compared to in '15 compared to '14 in the first half of 2014, that rate base was based on December 2012 rate base, and that carried through for the first 5 months, and that $683 million. When I look at the comparison of the second half of of 2014, that rate base is going to be around $922 million compared to the $1.8 billion. And you're right, the ROE that we've used for the second half of last year was 12.38%, and we'll recognize 11.06 the second half of 2015. With that said, I would expect that transmission will trend to the upper end of the range as we said most of our segments are.

componenttext: So I just want to add, we're very happy with the settlement. We wouldn't have settled if we weren't. componenttext: So what I said in my remarks is once we have -- we got the cash flow improvement done and once we have the results of the capacity performance and once we know where we're at with the ESP, then we will look at whether there's an application for equity to stimulate growth both in transmission and distribution, if any. So how long. I do not want to have to use equity repair our credit metrics and strengthening the balance sheet. That's why we implemented this project. I think we made substantial progress there as that starts to flow through to, to strengthening our balance sheet, strengthening our cash flow, strengthening our FFO because about 2/3 of it is O&M, and then we'll see what the other 2 land, and then we'll go from there and when we have analyst meeting, hopefully, early next year then we'll tell you where we're at with that, a little more definitively.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: When FERC made the decision about demand in response to the transitional options, I was just wondering, to what extent is that affect your thoughts with regards to the company's ability to not have to issue equity with regards to the competitive business,
componenttext: When FERC made the decision about demand in response to the transitional options, I was just wondering, to what extent is that affect your thoughts with regards to the company's ability to not have to issue equity with regards to the competitive business, if at all?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think I've sat here ever thinking about issuing equity for the competitive business. And I think once the results of the cash flow improvement process, which substantial part were -- was result of the competitive business stepping up, their partic
componenttext: I don't think I've sat here ever thinking about issuing equity for the competitive business. And I think once the results of the cash flow improvement process, which substantial part were -- was result of the competitive business stepping up, their particular credit metrics are going to look very strong. It's going to make a big impact on that part of the company. It makes an impact on the overall FirstEnergy credit metrics, too, but a substantial impact into the competitive business. So we think were going to be fine there for the foreseeable future. we already had that business in a position where it was cash flow positive for the next 4 years. This makes it substantially more cash flow positive, which was the second factor in the decision to go forward with demand dewatering. All the CapEx for the project was already in the 4-year plan and already in a plan that was cash flow positive, but we've now got some margin there. And as I've said along, the game plan with that, business is to keep it cash flow positive and take that positive cash flow and eventually use it to start paying back the holding company for some of the loans that we made to that business a few years ago. So that's the long-term plan there.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question comes the line of Paul Patterson with Glenrock Associates.
componenttext: The next question comes the line of Paul Patterson with Glenrock Associates.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question, so you guys have been -- Chuck, you've been making the round of the editorial boards, and there'd been some interesting quotes and what-have-you. And I know sometimes when you're being report on may not come out exactly as you did get it b
componenttext: First question, so you guys have been -- Chuck, you've been making the round of the editorial boards, and there'd been some interesting quotes and what-have-you. And I know sometimes when you're being report on may not come out exactly as you did get it but I'm just wondering if you could elaborate a little bit more on this, your comments about reregulation, trends in the company, things like that and how that fits in with the ESP proposal that you have, the PPA proposal and just sort of comment a little more of that.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, let's first talk a little bit about how newspapers run. We went and met with the editorial board, and we had what I thought was a good conversation over an 1 hour and 50 minutes that then gets boiled down into an article. Once that articles written,
componenttext: Well, let's first talk a little bit about how newspapers run. We went and met with the editorial board, and we had what I thought was a good conversation over an 1 hour and 50 minutes that then gets boiled down into an article. Once that articles written, there's a headline writer who goes and writes a headline that tries to draw attention to that article. The headline that was written for that article was completely inaccurate as to anything we discussed during that interview. In the interview, I was asked specific question of are we in anyway, working to get the legislature of the state to consider re-regulating, and my answer was no. In the context of the discussion about the PPAs, here's my view. We are talking about trying to find ways to preserve major generating assets that have plenty of useful life left in them and keep them from closing prematurely. Exelon is looking at doing do that in Illinois and New York. Ohio utilities are looking at doing it in Ohio. You don't ever hear any conversation about needing to do that in states that are regulated. Regulated states have plenty of generation. Then have integrated resource plans. And if they need more generation, they either buy or build it, so they are assured they have adequate generation to serve their customers. So these PPAs, I see, as a bridge to keep these plants alive long enough to allow whatever happens. If our state wants to look at that issue over time, great. But it's not that happen fast enough for these 2 plants. If we are ultimately able to make significant corrections in the market to make sure they provide for the long-term security of baseload-generating facilities, great. But I don't think we have time to wait on that either. And yesterday, the Senate Energy Committee put forth a bill that talks about asking the markets to kind of come up with a process to make sure they ensure diversity of both fuel and types of capacity across the markets. We don't have to wait on that either. These plans are at risk today, and we need to get a decision made as to whether we're going to look at ways to protect him so we left all of those debates and legislation in Washington, D.C. and everything else play out.

componenttext: Greetings and welcome to the FirstEnergy Corp. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Meghan Beringer, Director of Investor Relations for FirstEnergy. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brenda, and good morning. Welcome to FirstEnergy's second quarter earnings call. Today, we will make various forward-looking statements regarding revenues, earnings, performance, strategies and prospects. These statements are based on current expe
componenttext:
Thanks, Brenda, and good morning. Welcome to FirstEnergy's second quarter earnings call. Today, we will make various forward-looking statements regarding revenues, earnings, performance, strategies and prospects. These statements are based on current expectations and are subject to risk and uncertainty. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those indicated by such statements can be found on the Investors section of our website under the Earnings Information link and in our SEC filings. 
We will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures are also available on our website. 
Participating in today's call are Chuck Jones, President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Pearson, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Leila Vespoli, Executive Vice President, Markets and Chief Legal Officer; Donny Schneider, President of FirstEnergy Solutions; Jon Taylor, Vice President, Controller and Chief Accounting Officer; Steve Staub, Vice President and Treasurer; Don Moul, Vice President, Commodity Operations; and Irene Prezelj, Vice President, Investor Relations. 
Now I will turn the call over to Chuck Jones.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Meghan. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. I'm pleased to have this opportunity to share an update on what has been a very busy and productive period for FirstEnergy. We're continuing to make steady progress on our strategic initiat
componenttext:
Thanks, Meghan. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us. I'm pleased to have this opportunity to share an update on what has been a very busy and productive period for FirstEnergy. We're continuing to make steady progress on our strategic initiatives. We're achieving closure on several of the industry issues that impact our company, and we reported very strong financial results for the second quarter. Our efforts to position FirstEnergy for a stable, predictable and customer service-driven growth remain on track, and I'm optimistic about our future. 
During my remarks today, I will review a number of recent developments and give you a sense of what we expect for the rest of the year. Following my comments and Jim's review of our financial and operating results, we'll have plenty of time for your questions. 
Our operating earnings for the second quarter were $0.53 per share, which is $0.03 above the top of the range we provided in May. These results were higher -- these results were driven by higher earnings in our transmission business and the benefits of our more conservative strategy in our competitive business. We continue to make solid progress on our Energizing the Future transmission initiative, which as you know is expected to be the primary driver of our growth for the next several years. 
During the second quarter, we completed the project designed to support service reliability following the plant deactivations in Northern Ohio, and we continue our work to upgrade and strengthen the grid in the ATSI region and support midstream gas operations. We remain on pace to invest $970 million in our transmission business during 2015 with about 60% of this investment already complete. 
This year, we have also put into place the framework to ensure more timely recovery for our transmission investments. In January, we moved to a forward-looking formula rate structure for ATSI; and on July 20, we filed with FERC a settlement agreement that maintains ATSI's ROE at 12.38% for the first 6 months of this year. Under the settlement, which remains subject to FERC approval, the rate adjust to 11.06% for the second half of this year and then to 10.38% beginning January 1, 2016 until at least January 1, 2018. The average ROE for the 3-year period would be 10.83%. We are pleased to reach the settlement as it reflects to current transmission ROE environment and allows us to move forward with our Energizing the Future transmission investment plan for customers while ensuring timely recovery for the company. We expect approval from FERC later this year. 
In June, we filed request for authorization to transfer transmission assets owned by Met-Ed, Penelec and JCP&L into a new transmission affiliate called Mid-Atlantic Interstate Transmission or MAIT. These assets represent approximately $900 million in rate base as of the end of 2014. If approved by FERC, the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission and the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities, MAIT will operate similarly to our 2 existing transmission subsidiaries, ATSI and TrAILCo. We expect this structure to facilitate investments that can improve service reliability for customers of our Eastern utility companies similar to what we are doing for customers connected to our ANSI -- ATSI transmission system. We are seeking approval from FERC in 6 months and from the state commissions by mid-2016. Prior to closing the transaction, MAIT will file for new transmission rates with FERC. 
In May, I outlined 3 key initiatives that will shape our company going forward. These are the cash flow improvement project, PJM capacity market reforms and our Ohio ESP. 
Let's start with the results of our cash flow improvement project. I'm pleased to report that we expect this project to result in cash flow improvements of $58 million in 2015, $155 million in 2016 and $240 million in 2017, exceeding the original targets for all 3 years. We launched this project in April with the goal of capturing both immediate and long-term savings that are meaningful and sustainable. We have completed a thorough analysis of savings and process improvements that do not compromise our ability to serve the needs of our organization, our customers and our employees. And we are now moving forward to implement these plans. These improvements come primarily from our competitive and corporate functions. The largest categories include: reducing expenses and capital at our competitive fleet, particularly at our subcritical fossil units; reducing fossil fuel and fuel-related commodity expenses; and taking advantage of attrition across the company and implementing a selective hiring program. There are also nearly 100 smaller items that collectively make a strong impact. About 65% of these savings are expected from operating expenses and 35% are from capital and nuclear fuel improvements over the 3-year period. 
On Page 170 of our FactBook, which was posted on our website last evening, we include more details on the cash flow initiative. 
We've already begun the implementation process. In fact, the majority of the fuel savings that we identified have already been locked in, and the new contract pricing will begin in September. We've also established a project management office to ensure we capture these savings and are fully committed to successfully executing this plan and establishing a new foundation for FirstEnergy going forward. We believe it will result in a stronger and more flexible company with an improved balance sheet over time. 
Turning to capacity market reforms. During the quarter, FERC approved PJM's new capacity performance roles, and as you know, FERC issued an order last week allowing demand response and energy efficiency resources into the transitional options. Importantly, the base residual auction remains on track and is still scheduled to begin August 10. The 2016- '17 and 2017- '18 transitional auctions were delayed slightly and are now scheduled to begin on August 26 and September 3, respectively. 
Before I move from generation, let's quickly touch on the Supreme Court decision regarding MATS. While the EPA regulations remain in effect pending further judicial proceedings before the D.C. Circuit Court, I want to be clear that FirstEnergy is not contemplating reopening any of the units representing 4,769 megawatts of generation that were closed due to cost of compliance with the MATS regulation. For our remaining fleet, we have already spent a significant portion of the $370 million in capital expenditures for equipment upgrades that were acquired under MATS, and many projects are complete or underway. In our competitive generation fleet, we identified a total cost of $178 million to comply with the regulations, of which $62 million had been spent through June 30 this year. At our regulated fleet, the cost estimate was $192 million with $105 million of that spent through June 30. 
I will also mention that we are moving forward with all aspects of the construction of the new dewatering facility for our 2,400-megawatt Bruce Mansfield Plant in Pennsylvania. While the plant is still pressured by current market conditions, we believe moving forward with construction is prudent to ensure that these megawatts remain available to serve customers in 2017 after our disposal rates at Little Blue Run expire. As we have previously mentioned, all costs associated with this project are in our current capital plan. 
Finally, let's move to our Ohio and our electric security plan. Based on the current procedural schedules, staff testimony is due August 14 with hearings to begin at the end of the month. As you would expect, we remain very engaged in this process. We filed supplemental testimony in early May to further emphasize the factors that the Ohio Commission outlined in the ADP and Duke cases. It is telling that the public utilities that serve the majority of customers in the state agree conceptually on an appropriate transition plan toward a future that ensures safe, reliable, clean and affordable power for all Ohio customers from industrial facilities to homeowners. Given the plant's benefits, including the economic development support, we believe our filing meets the criteria outlined by the commission, and we remain optimistic that this plan will result in sound state energy policy for our customers. 
We had a solid first half. Since the start of the year, we have made tremendous progress toward our goals of investing in customer-focused growth supporting sound energy policy and strengthening our company from within, and we know there is still work to be done to position FirstEnergy for the future. 
At this point, we are reaffirming our 2015 operating earnings guidance range of $2.40 a share to $2.70 a share with all 3 of our operating segments trending favorably versus their midpoints. We're comfortable guiding to the top of this range. We expect to refine guidance on the third quarter call once we have seen the full effects of the summer weather. 
Collectively, the cash flow improvement initiative, upcoming capacity auction results and Ohio ESP decision will drive the near-term financial strategy of our company and give us a much clearer view of the next 3 years, including earnings and cash flow and a determination on additional equity, if any, to drive growth in our regulated businesses. 
In addition, we have already begun our robust annual planning process, which includes updating projections for all of our utilities, especially now that we have the 3 major rate cases behind us. This effort will help us further refine our distribution utility earnings profile going forward. 
Many of you have asked about the status of our Analyst Meeting. At this time, we still intend to hold it after the outcome of the Ohio ESP, which may push the meeting into early 2016. We look forward to providing you a comprehensive view of our future planning at that time. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Jim for a brief review of our second quarter financial results.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. My prepared remarks will focus on the major drivers and events of the quarter. As you know, more details are available in the consolidated report that was posted on our website yesterday evening, and as always, w
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. My prepared remarks will focus on the major drivers and events of the quarter. As you know, more details are available in the consolidated report that was posted on our website yesterday evening, and as always, we welcome your questions either in the Q&A or following the call. 
Today, we reported strong second quarter 2015 operating earnings of $0.53 per share, which compares to $0.49 per share last year. On a GAAP basis, basic earnings were $0.44 per share for the second quarter of 2015. GAAP earnings were $0.16 per basic share during the same period last year. As Chuck mentioned, our operating earnings were above our targeted range for the quarter. 
Let's look at the results from each of our segments starting with the distribution business. Residential sales decreased 0.7% overall compared to the second quarter of 2014 while commercial sales increased 1%. Adjusting for weather, residential deliveries were down 2.4%, and commercial sales were flat. We are examining the residential usage trend, which has been down over the last 4 quarters on a weather-adjusted basis. We believe this is attributable to energy efficiency as average customer usage has also declined quarter-over-quarter. 
In the industrial sector, sales decreased 1.1% in the quarter ending a 7-quarter run of increased demand from the customer class primarily due to lower usage from the steel industry. 
The current rate of shale growth continues to be impacted by soft natural gas prices. While we still see support from more than 1,000 megawatts of new load from midstream activity through 2019, our forecast reflect greater confidence in the 2015 and 2016 projects, which represent about half of that load growth. 
Turning to our transmission business. Second quarter operating earnings increased $0.06 to $0.21 per share as a result of revenue increases from a higher rate base at ATSI and the forward-looking rate structure that began in January. 
In our competitive business, operating earnings increased $0.01 per share compared to the same period last year reflecting higher commodity margin associated with higher-capacity revenues, a modest increase in wholesale sales and lower contract sales. Additionally, operating cost decreased year-over-year largely due to improved plant performance. 
As we said last quarter, we have essentially sold everything we anticipated for 2015 on a retail and forward wholesale basis with a reserve of 5 million-megawatt hours available for spot wholesale sales through the end of the year. For 2016, about 70% of our expected generation resources are committed, and we are currently about 40% committed for 2017. 
Based on our results for the first half of the year and the projected savings from the cash flow improvement initiative, we are reaffirming our 2015 adjusted EBITDA range for the competitive business of $875 million to $950 million and increasing our 2016 adjusted EBITDA range to $825 million to $925 million from $750 million to $850 million. 
It was another solid quarter for our company, and this is shaping up to be a good year. As Chuck said, we are reaffirming our operating earnings guidance, and the trends we see so far this year make us confident at the top end of that range at this point. We are committed to achieving the cash savings we have identified and to building long-term shareholder value through our customer-focused regulated growth strategy. 
Now with that, I'd like to open the call for your questions.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Dan Eggers with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Dan Eggers with Crédit Suisse.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, in the sense of being greedy, 2 questions. One, what do you see for opportunities going forward? Can those numbers grow as you kind of get further into the process of evaluation? And then, two, can you talk a little bit about how you were able to
componenttext: I guess, in the sense of being greedy, 2 questions. One, what do you see for opportunities going forward? Can those numbers grow as you kind of get further into the process of evaluation? And then, two, can you talk a little bit about how you were able to get such big fuel savings out of suppliers? You seem to be pretty in financially dire straits at this point?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, tell you what, I'll take the first question, and then I'll hand the second part of it off to Don Moul to answer. And on the first one, I do think there are some opportunities for us to add to this over time, particularly in the supply chain area. We
componenttext: Well, tell you what, I'll take the first question, and then I'll hand the second part of it off to Don Moul to answer. And on the first one, I do think there are some opportunities for us to add to this over time, particularly in the supply chain area. We set a 12-week time frame to complete this study. We can operate at that speed, but our suppliers don't all necessarily operate at that speed. So we've got a number of items in the queue that we're still working on to try to get across the finish line, so I think there is some opportunity to improve these over time. And I'll let Don tackle your fuel question.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Chuck. And so when you take a look at the CFIP savings, as you noted, Dan, one of the most significant savings, and the initiative comes from the reduction in the fossil fuel cost. And that total savings is about $151 million. It kind of brea
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Chuck. And so when you take a look at the CFIP savings, as you noted, Dan, one of the most significant savings, and the initiative comes from the reduction in the fossil fuel cost. And that total savings is about $151 million. It kind of breaks out as follows: about $50 million or $75 million of the savings is really a result of working with our coal suppliers to get reduced rates, and then we got about $50 million associated with the refined coal process where we partnered with several third parties to produce a coal that reduces emissions. We have a contractual relationship where we pay for every ton of coal that's treated, and the third party receives a tax credit under Section 45 of the tax code. These contracts are now in place at Sammis and Mansfield through 2021, and we're in the final steps of negotiating for Pleasants. The balance, which is about $25 million, is driven from several smaller items including reagent and waste disposal cost. And as Chuck said, these are already under contract. So that's part of the breakdown of the savings, and clearly, the coal suppliers are in tight market times as well as we are. We found opportunities to build on our relationships. We've got good relationships with our coal suppliers and our transportation suppliers. We meet with them twice a year to work through these market challenges and try to find ways that we can partner in a win-win kind of an approach, so we have -- we've been successful so far. We look forward to working with them in the future.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll just follow on a second there because I know I'm going to get this question later. The savings we were able to achieve in the fuel supply, particularly related to the Bruce Mansfield Plant, were a big factor in our decision to move forward with the d
componenttext: I'll just follow on a second there because I know I'm going to get this question later. The savings we were able to achieve in the fuel supply, particularly related to the Bruce Mansfield Plant, were a big factor in our decision to move forward with the dewatering facility. It makes that plant more competitive starting September 1.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. I guess can we turn to the Ohio PPA structure? It kind of -- it keeps getting pushed out from a time perspective. Should we read anything to maybe some change in tone at the governor level or the commission level? What's their interest in do
componenttext: Okay. Got it. I guess can we turn to the Ohio PPA structure? It kind of -- it keeps getting pushed out from a time perspective. Should we read anything to maybe some change in tone at the governor level or the commission level? What's their interest in doing this? And then do you see any risk to -- maybe interest change in once EPA comes with the carbon rules or once RPM gets out there?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll let Leila take it, and I may follow on.
componenttext: I'll let Leila take it, and I may follow on.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Chuck. Dan, I think the delay in the hearing was in response to the commission's desire to get additional data points with regard to what's happening with the EPA, but I think more precisely, what's happening with the capacity performance. I
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Chuck. Dan, I think the delay in the hearing was in response to the commission's desire to get additional data points with regard to what's happening with the EPA, but I think more precisely, what's happening with the capacity performance. I don't think that, that should be the be-all, end-all. I think those are data points, but I also think they are mindful of the fact that our current ESP ends the middle of next year. So there's not a lot of additional delays that could be tolerated within the schedule we need to meet, so I think we are in a good place right now with regard to the timing of it, with hearings starting August 31. One thing I'd like to point out, it was after the last call that we continue to be in negotiations. And since our last call, we were able to add IEU as a nonopposing party and Kroger as assigned party. So I think what is presented to the commission is a very robust settlement. Still -- I'm still very hopeful that we'll be able to move forward in a very positive way. And as always, we continue to try and bring additional parties on board.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So to your question on how does it tie into the Clean Power Plan and other things that are going on, I don't think we have time to wait to see how all of those shake out. There's a sense of urgency here, I think, around these 2 facilities in particular th
componenttext: So to your question on how does it tie into the Clean Power Plan and other things that are going on, I don't think we have time to wait to see how all of those shake out. There's a sense of urgency here, I think, around these 2 facilities in particular that we've got to get a decision made about them. So obviously, we're anxious to keep it moving forward.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me just clarify, the time line is -- the hearings are August 31. Please work through the -- lay on maybe the steps there to refine a resolution that should play out if it goes fully litigated through without a settlement?
componenttext: Let me just clarify, the time line is -- the hearings are August 31. Please work through the -- lay on maybe the steps there to refine a resolution that should play out if it goes fully litigated through without a settlement?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So at this point, I would like to say we would get it done by the end of the year, but I'm thinking it might slip into the very first part of next year, so early 2016 for a final decision.
componenttext: So at this point, I would like to say we would get it done by the end of the year, but I'm thinking it might slip into the very first part of next year, so early 2016 for a final decision.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from the line of Neel Mitra with Tudor Pickering Holt.
componenttext: And the next question comes from the line of Neel Mitra with Tudor Pickering Holt.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: The transmission business seems to be doing well, and I think in the past, you mentioned that maybe about $1 billion is the maximum you can spend a year. Is that number still right? Or could you deploy additional capital beyond that $1 billion if the proc
componenttext: The transmission business seems to be doing well, and I think in the past, you mentioned that maybe about $1 billion is the maximum you can spend a year. Is that number still right? Or could you deploy additional capital beyond that $1 billion if the process goes well and the Pennsylvania Utilities are included in the transcos?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there are several factors. We've communicated our plans for the next several years, and they amount to about $1 billion a year. MAIT will provide additional opportunities if we're successful in getting it done. Our transmission infrastructur
componenttext: Well, I think there are several factors. We've communicated our plans for the next several years, and they amount to about $1 billion a year. MAIT will provide additional opportunities if we're successful in getting it done. Our transmission infrastructure has aged, and we've talked about a queue of projects that could potentially go on for a long time at the rate of $1 billion a year. So I think at that point in time, we would look at it. But I think a determining factor is the ability to resource additional construction. There is a shortage of transmission alignment around our country, and that would be a factor in terms of expanding it to any significant amount, I think.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then the second question on Davis-Besse and Sammis. Obviously, you need both the capacity auction and the PPA for the plants to be successful. How do you philosophically think about the strategy around bidding in the PJM without a PPA resoluti
componenttext: Got it. And then the second question on Davis-Besse and Sammis. Obviously, you need both the capacity auction and the PPA for the plants to be successful. How do you philosophically think about the strategy around bidding in the PJM without a PPA resolution in hand?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, our attack is to bid those units as competitive units. That's what they are today, and I would just correct one thing you said. I don't think we need both. I think we need the PPAs. If we're successful there, what happens in the capacity auctions ev
componenttext: Well, our attack is to bid those units as competitive units. That's what they are today, and I would just correct one thing you said. I don't think we need both. I think we need the PPAs. If we're successful there, what happens in the capacity auctions even though they are bid as competitive units? That value will flow to customers once the PPA is approved.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Gregg Orrill with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Gregg Orrill with Barclays.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could comment on the appeals to the Supreme Court of the -- of Ohio, of the AP -- PPA proposal whether that's relevant, whether you think that's relevant to your case at all and if you care to comment on whether you think the Suprem
componenttext: I was wondering if you could comment on the appeals to the Supreme Court of the -- of Ohio, of the AP -- PPA proposal whether that's relevant, whether you think that's relevant to your case at all and if you care to comment on whether you think the Supreme Court will take the case.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Gregg, this is Leila. I think right now that those appeals are premature. There is still adjudicatory hearing associated with that case. And in Ohio, I don't see how you get the Supreme Court to tape those up when adjudicatory hearing are pending. So I ab
componenttext: Gregg, this is Leila. I think right now that those appeals are premature. There is still adjudicatory hearing associated with that case. And in Ohio, I don't see how you get the Supreme Court to tape those up when adjudicatory hearing are pending. So I absolutely expect those cases, those appeals to be dismissed. Doesn't mean they can't refile them a later date, but again, I think they're premature. So I don't think they're going to have any effect on our case, and with regard -- I read some conjecture that if they went forward somehow, things would be stayed in Ohio. If a case is going before the Ohio Supreme Court, the decision goes forward, commission decision goes forward, and is not stayed unless a specific statutory provision is met. And in order to that provision, the party that is requesting the stay needs to provide a -- and post a bond. So that's a very high hurdle to assume within the context of these type of cases. So again, bottom line, no effect.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Arnold with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Jonathan Arnold with Deutsche Bank.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Quick question on the transmission. Again, you booked -- you're up, I guess, $0.11 in the first half of the year. Is there anything in those numbers for the settlement that give you -- do we take in some kind of a charge against the lower ROE this quarter
componenttext: Quick question on the transmission. Again, you booked -- you're up, I guess, $0.11 in the first half of the year. Is there anything in those numbers for the settlement that give you -- do we take in some kind of a charge against the lower ROE this quarter? Or is that all to come in H2 when the things finalized?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there wasn't a lower ROE this quarter. We got 12.38% in place for the first 6 months of 2015, which was a partial contributor to the better performance in the transmission segment.
componenttext: Well, there wasn't a lower ROE this quarter. We got 12.38% in place for the first 6 months of 2015, which was a partial contributor to the better performance in the transmission segment.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: But I'm just curious, Chuck, whether you might have had to recognize the lower return that will come in the second half of the year ahead of time, but it sounds like no.
componenttext: But I'm just curious, Chuck, whether you might have had to recognize the lower return that will come in the second half of the year ahead of time, but it sounds like no.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we won't, Jonathan. We will recognize those during the period that they occur.
componenttext: No, we won't, Jonathan. We will recognize those during the period that they occur.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the moving parts, as we think about the second half, the transmission is higher rate base, having the forward-looking test year for the second half of the year and tempered somewhat by ROE?
componenttext: So the moving parts, as we think about the second half, the transmission is higher rate base, having the forward-looking test year for the second half of the year and tempered somewhat by ROE?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say, Jonathan, for the second half of the year, you won't see the robust growth that we saw on the first quarter. We were up $0.11 year-over-year for the second quarter -- or for the second half of the year, you're going to have a much higher
componenttext: Yes, I would say, Jonathan, for the second half of the year, you won't see the robust growth that we saw on the first quarter. We were up $0.11 year-over-year for the second quarter -- or for the second half of the year, you're going to have a much higher rate base that you're going to compare to in '15 compared to '14 in the first half of 2014. That rate base was based on December 2012 rate base, and that carried through for the first 5 months. And that was $683 million. When I look at the comparison of the second half of 2014, that rate base is going to be about $922 million compared to the $1.8 billion. And you're right, the ROE that was used for the second half of last year was 12.38%, and we'll recognize 11.06% the second half of 2015. With that said, I would expect that transmission will trend to the upper end of the range as we said most of our segments are.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. But still the math, more or less, gets you there when you add all those parts together?
componenttext: Okay. But still the math, more or less, gets you there when you add all those parts together?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's right. That's right.
componenttext: That's right. That's right.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I just want to add, we're very happy with the settlement. We wouldn't have settled it if we weren't. And if you think about what we're doing, $500 million of investment in our transmission business, the difference between 10.38% and 12.38% adds to mayb
componenttext: So I just want to add, we're very happy with the settlement. We wouldn't have settled it if we weren't. And if you think about what we're doing, $500 million of investment in our transmission business, the difference between 10.38% and 12.38% adds to maybe $10 million, maybe $0.015 a share overall. But as we talked earlier, the forward-looking rate returns cash and earnings back to the business faster and more timely given the way we're investing in smaller projects to get done quickly.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we can cash out, and we think that getting the clarity on ROE is a big help, too. So I just wanted to understand the math of bridging the second half.
componenttext: So we can cash out, and we think that getting the clarity on ROE is a big help, too. So I just wanted to understand the math of bridging the second half.

componenttext: So that's with respect to FERC and then to Pennsylvania interventions, August 3, prehearing conferences in sometime August, September date and then a decision, mid-2016. And with respect to New Jersey, no deadline interventions, and we would expect an order again with regard to that by mid-2016. So no specific hearing date.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then is there precedents in Pennsylvania, New Jersey for others that have been able to get kind of existing transmission kind of separated out?
componenttext: Okay. And then is there precedents in Pennsylvania, New Jersey for others that have been able to get kind of existing transmission kind of separated out?
