headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the FirstEnergy Corp. Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Meghan Beringer, Director of Investor Rela
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the FirstEnergy Corp. Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Meghan Beringer, Director of Investor Relations for FirstEnergy Corp. Thank you, Ms.  Beringer, you may begin.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rob. Good morning, and welcome to our third quarter earnings call. Today, we will make various forward-looking statements regarding revenues, earnings, performance, strategies and prospects. These statements are based on current expectations and
componenttext:
Thanks, Rob. Good morning, and welcome to our third quarter earnings call. 
Today, we will make various forward-looking statements regarding revenues, earnings, performance, strategies and prospects. These statements are based on current expectations and are subject to certain risks and uncertainties. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those indicated by such statements can be found on the Investors section of our website under the Earnings Information Link and in our SEC filings. 
We will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures are also available on our website.
Participating in today's call are: Chuck Jones, President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Pearson, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Donny Schneider, President of FirstEnergy Solutions; Jon Taylor, Vice President, Controller and Chief Accounting Officer; Steve Staub, Vice President and Treasurer; and Irene Prezelj, Vice President, Investor Relations.
Now I will turn the call over to Chuck Jones.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Meghan. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. We are pleased to report another solid quarter for FirstEnergy. Last night, we reported third quarter operating earnings of $0.98 per share, which is $0.06 above the top of our guid
componenttext:
Thanks, Meghan. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. 
We are pleased to report another solid quarter for FirstEnergy. Last night, we reported third quarter operating earnings of $0.98 per share, which is $0.06 above the top of our guidance range for the quarter. As Jim will discuss in greater detail, these results reflect a solid performance across all 3 of our business segments.  Based on our strong third quarter and year-to-date performance, we are raising and narrowing our full year 2015 operating earnings guidance to a range of $2.67 to $2.75 per share from a previous range of $2.40 to $2.70 per share. 
This is shaping up to be a great year for FirstEnergy, and as we look forward to 2016, our employees can be proud of what they have achieved. In addition to strong earnings, we have made tremendous progress on key initiatives that can provide us with greater strength and flexibility as we work to achieve our future goals.  So far this year, we have clarity on the results from 2 of these initiatives: the Cash Flow Improvement Project and PJM market capacity reforms. And we continue to make progress on the third initiative, the Ohio ESP.
As we discussed in July, our Cash Flow Improvement Project exceeded our initial target and should generate at least $240 million in cash flow improvements by 2017. That project, which solicit cost savings ideas from across the company, is rolling out as we expected. And we remain fully on track to capture the $58 million in cash flow improvements identified for 2015.  Overall, this effort is not only establishing a new cost structure for the company, it has also helped us initiate a culture change around spending. Employees continue to provide suggestions for meaningful and sustainable ways to reduce our cost structure, which could drive modest incremental savings going forward on top of what we have already communicated.
We are also cautiously optimistic about capacity market reforms that are now in place at PJM. Results from the base residual and transitional auctions held in August and September were in line with our expectations, with a pay-for-performance model resulting in clearing prices that come closer to reflecting the two -- true operating costs of our generating plants.
You will recall that we raised our 2016 adjusted EBITDA guidance range for our competitive business in September as a result of the higher capacity prices and all of our uncommitted generation clearing to transitional auction for the 2016, 2017 delivery years, and we are reaffirming that range. We're also raising and narrowing our 2015 adjusted EBITDA guidance based on our year-to-date results and the impact of our cash flow initiative.
While Jim will provide more of the details about adjusted EBITDA for our competitive business in a few minutes, I wanted to take a moment to address our current thinking about 2017. All of our uncommitted generation cleared the 2017, 2018 transitional auction as well. But as you know, our proposed purchase power agreement in Ohio will impact generation sales for 7 months in 2016 and the full year of 2017. So while we considered providing an adjusted EBITDA range for 2017 on this call, we ultimately decided that we do not have enough information yet to offer a constructive view.  We remain committed to being transparent, and we intend to provide you with this outlook once there is more clarity.
With that said, we are pleased that the combination of our cash flow initiative and PJM capacity revenues from recent auctions will further strengthen the overall cash flow position for our competitive business. And you will recall that we already expected that business to be cash flow positive through at least 2018, prior to the incremental benefits of these 2 initiatives.
Many of you have asked if we intend to shut down additional plants. I tell our employees we are working hard to ensure all remaining generation remains viable. The results of the Ohio ESP and future auctions will give us a better understanding of the longer-term outlook on our at risk baseload power plants, and we continue to consider fuel and transportation contracts as well as environmental matters such as the EPA's Clean Power plan, which was finalized in August.
We are particularly interested in treatment of existing nuclear generation state specific emission reduction targets to compliance time line and flexibility. While we are advocating for an interpretation that allows for a thoughtful engineering-based approach to ensure reliable energy resources for our customers, we will not have full clarity on the rule's impact until state implementation plans are submitted, which could be as late as 2018, and then approved by the EPA.
To ensure that our critical baseload power plants continue operating and to help safeguard our customers against price increases and volatility, we remain committed to our Ohio electric security plan. The evidentiary hearing for the ESP began on August 31, and rebuttal testimony was filed last week. We currently expect a decision by early 2016, and we continue our discussions with the staff and other parties to reach a positive outcome for Ohio customers.
In fact, you may have noticed that Leila is not in the call today. She is in Columbus working with the ESP as we speak, and I think that's where we would all rather have her. Once we have an outcome in Ohio, we have the information necessary to more fully assess FirstEnergy's earnings for 2016, regulated growth in future years as well as our cash flow over the next several years. As we had talked about previously, at that point, we will determine future equity needs, if any, to help support our regulated growth initiatives.
We're also laying the groundwork for sustainable reliability investments in Pennsylvania. Last week, our 4 utilities in the state filed long-term infrastructure improvement plans for the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission. In total, these plans call for a projected increase in capital investment of nearly $245 million over the next 5 years to strengthen, upgrade and modernize our distribution systems. We're anticipating the PUC's approval of the LTIP proposals by mid-February. Once we have approval of the plan, we will use the distribution system improvement charge at each company to recover the appropriate fixed costs that are part of the plans.
In New Jersey, we're further enhancing our current service reliability program with an additional $25 million spending in 2015. These expenditures, which are expected to have a $0.04 per share impact on fourth quarter 2015 earnings, will not only enhance our current service reliability program, but also demonstrate our commitment to make JCP&L a stronger company.
Of course, significant part of our growth plan includes our Energizing the Future transmission initiative, which remains on pace to invest $970 million this year with about 80% of that amount spent year-to-date.  Recent projects include final planning and preliminary site work for a new substation near Smithfield, West Virginia that will support the shale gas industry and enhance service reliability in monpower. We're also nearing completion on a transmission reinforcement project including a substation in 6-mile 138 in Harrison County, West Virginia that will enhance service reliability for more than 14,000 Mon Power customers in Harrison, Lewis and Gilmore counties. We expect the substation to be energized in December.
We are pleased to report that late yesterday afternoon, FERC approved our settlement agreement for ATSI's forward-looking formula rate structure. In addition, our proposal to move our Met-Ed, Penelec and JCP&L transmission assets into a new affiliate called Mid-Atlantic Interstate Transmission, or MAIT, is moving through the FERC and state approval processes. We continue to seek final state approval for MAIT by mid-2016. If approved, we expect this structure to facilitate investments that can improve service reliability for these utility customers.
Lastly, we remain committed to holding an analyst meeting after we have results from our Ohio case.
Now I'll turn the call over to Jim for a brief review of the quarter and our expectation for the remainder of the year. As always, we will reserve plenty of time for your questions before the end of the hour.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. Before I get started, I will remind you that more detailed information about the quarter can be found in the consolidated report that was posted to our website yesterday evening. We also welcome your questions in
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. Before I get started, I will remind you that more detailed information about the quarter can be found in the consolidated report that was posted to our website yesterday evening. We also welcome your questions in the Q&A or following the call.
Our strong third quarter operating earnings of $0.98 per share compared to $0.89 per share in the third quarter of 2014.  On a GAAP basis, earnings were $0.94 per share for the third quarter of 2015 compared to $0.79 per share during the same period last year.  Our operating earnings primarily reflects higher distribution sales and the net impact of previously resolved rate cases, higher transmission revenues that resulted from our Energizing the Future initiative and ATSI forward-looking rate structure and higher commodity margin in our competitive business, partially offset by higher operating expenses and a higher effective tax rate.
In our distribution business, residential sales increased 9%, and commercial sales increased 2.6% compared to the third quarter of 2014, primarily resulting from cooling degree days that were 36% higher than last year and 13% above normal.  Adjusting for weather, however, residential deliveries decreased nearly 1% and commercial sales were down 2.4%, reflecting the impact of energy efficiency mandate.  As we mentioned during our second quarter call, we are examining the usage trend in all 3 customer classes, particularly the impact of energy efficiency on residential usage. And we will be prepared to discuss our load forecast in more detail during our analyst meeting. However, we do believe we are seeing the effects of energy-efficient lighting sooner and with a larger impact than previous estimates.
In the industrial sector, sales decreased 3.2% in the quarter as a result of lower usage from our steel, coal mining and electrical equipment and manufacturing customers, partially offset by increased usage from the shale gas and automotive sectors.
In our transmission business, third quarter operating earnings increased $0.04 to $0.17 per share as a result of higher revenue associated with a higher rate base and ATSI's forward-looking rate structure, which began in January.
In our competitive business, operating earnings increased $0.09 per share compared to the third quarter of 2014. Commodity margin increased $0.15 per share due to favorable summer weather that was warm but not extreme, coupled with lower commodity cost. Contract sales volume decreased in line with our expectation while wholesale sales volume increased slightly. 
Variable margin benefited from higher capacity revenues, lower purchased power costs and fuel expense and lower transmission charges. Operating costs increased compared to the third quarter of 2014, primarily due to greater expenses related to a nuclear refueling outage this quarter at Beaver Valley 2.
We remain committed to our ongoing strategy of mitigating risks by reducing sales weather-sensitive channels and have reduced the size of our residential retail book by approximately 38% since the third quarter of 2014 and also reduced the size of our weather-sensitive commercial and industrial book over the same period.
Looking at our sales position, for 2016, we have about 59 million megawatt-hours or about 75% of our expected generation resources committed, and we are currently about 45% committed for 2017 with about 36 million megawatt-hours sold.
As Chuck discussed earlier, we are raising and narrowing our 2015 adjusted EBITDA range for the competitive business to $945 million to $975 million from $875 million to $950 million, based on our results for the first 9 months of the year and the projected savings from the Cash Flow Improvement Project. We are also reaffirming the 2016 adjusted EBITDA range that we provided in September of $950 million to $1,050,000,000. And as Chuck mentioned, we intend to provide 2017 adjusted EBITDA after the Ohio ESP is resolved.
Moving to other financial matters. During the September investor conferences, we received questions about our pension funding plan, so we wanted to spend a moment clarifying this topic. As we do each year, we disclosed our estimated pension funding requirements for the next several years as of December 31, 2014 in the Form 10-K that was filed in February. And as always, we include those future funding estimates in our internal long-term planning process. You'll recall that we contributed $143 million to our pension fund earlier this year. Consistent with our normal process, we will provide an update to our estimated funding requirements for future years when we file our 2015 Form 10-K this coming February.  
I will also note that we have essentially completed our financing plans for 2015, and our expected financing plans for 2016 do not include any issuance of long-term debt until the middle of next year.
As Chuck said earlier, 2015 is shaping up to be a strong and important year for FirstEnergy as we create a new framework for our future. We have raised our operating earnings guidance based on the success for strategies. And we are making solid progress towards our goals of building long-term value for shareholders through predictable customer-focused regulated growth.
Now I'd like to open the call for your questions.

componenttext: I don't think it complicates the opportunity for a settlement at all. I think we have the opportunity to settle the case all the way through any final outcome, actually. So it closes the record as far as anything new been introduced into the record as far as testimony and remote testimony, but it doesn't prohibit ongoing discussions.

componenttext: Maybe a follow-up there on generally how you're feeling about the process of negotiating the PPAs, and whether you feel you have better likelihood of nuclear versus coal?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well as I've said all along, I think that the plan that we filed is the best plan for the customers in Ohio. And we continue to work to educate the commission staff as best we can on why we believe that is the case. I think we're continuing to discuss cer
componenttext: Well as I've said all along, I think that the plan that we filed is the best plan for the customers in Ohio. And we continue to work to educate the commission staff as best we can on why we believe that is the case. I think we're continuing to discuss certain parameters around the filing, but I would expect that as we go forward, we're going to continue to talk about the PPA in somewhat the fashion that we filed it. Now having said that, there's always some room for negotiation, but I think the whole idea here is we filed a plan that's good for customers, protects them over the long haul. And at the end of the day, I told -- I've gone through the example of what happens when one plant -- plants close in the past. It creates spending and transmission that customers pay for. So I think this plan kind of is neutral to what the transmission spending would be, and I still think it's something we can get to across the goal line with.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just another question on pension mark-to-market and kind of your treatment there and -- but that doesn't show up in the earnings guidance. Are you thinking about that?
componenttext: And then just another question on pension mark-to-market and kind of your treatment there and -- but that doesn't show up in the earnings guidance. Are you thinking about that?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greg, this is Jim. Yes, it will not show up in our operating earnings guidance. We have historically treated that as a mark-to-market. In fact, if you look at our consolidated report, we put a disclosure in there of what the range of potential impact to o
componenttext: Greg, this is Jim. Yes, it will not show up in our operating earnings guidance. We have historically treated that as a mark-to-market. In fact, if you look at our consolidated report, we put a disclosure in there of what the range of potential impact to our GAAP earnings would be if we were to mark that pension plan effective September 30. Effective September 30, our plan had a loss on our return on assets of about 3.5% and the discount range was 4.25%. So we put a range in there assuming that our assets' return remain at that level and the discount rate would be anywhere between 4.25% and 4.5%. As you know, October's been a very good month in the equity markets. In fact, it's been one of the strongest months in history. So the return on our assets has improved somewhat. And if we had to mark that today, our discount range would be in the 4.5% range. So my expectation all things being equal, if they don't change from today, that range that we gave of $0.30 to $0.67, it would be at the lower end. In fact, it may be less than $0.37 and maybe less than $250 million that we disclosed. From a funding standpoint, we disclosed in the 10-K last year that it would be about $1,700,000,000 for the period '15 through '19. We did contributed $143 million this year. From a funding standpoint, we'll have to see where the discount rate is and where the return on assets are at the end of the year, but I don't expect anything to be materially different than what we disclosed in our 10-K in 2014.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just follow on a little bit to Jim's answer there. I think we've been very open in disclosing what our pension funding obligations might be and the impact on our GAAP earnings. But from the very beginning of me coming into this position, one of th
componenttext: I would just follow on a little bit to Jim's answer there. I think we've been very open in disclosing what our pension funding obligations might be and the impact on our GAAP earnings. But from the very beginning of me coming into this position, one of the things we talked about was earnings quality. And I think this quarter, $0.94 and $0.98 GAAP versus non-GAAP, we have really reduced that gap between GAAP and non-GAAP, as I told you I would. And I think our earnings quality for all 3 quarters is substantially improved, and that's the way we expect to operate going forward.

componenttext: I wouldn't expect it should have an impact on the discussions we're having in Ohio. headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure that the revolver borrowings increased $1 billion quarter-over-quarter. In fact, if you look at our entire financing plan for the entire year, we expect to increase that by just about $350 million year-over-year, and most of that will be new
componenttext: I'm not sure that the revolver borrowings increased $1 billion quarter-over-quarter. In fact, if you look at our entire financing plan for the entire year, we expect to increase that by just about $350 million year-over-year, and most of that will be new long-term debt associated with the distribution and transmission business. In fact, our revolver borrowings at the end of 2014 were about $1.8 billion, and my expectation is that they are going to be right in that range, maybe slightly less than that by the end of the year. So there's no real impact on our financing plans there.

And at this point in time, I'm not prepared to say what we expect that number to be '18 and beyond. But I think as we get through the Ohio ESP and we see the company that we have a base to build upon after that, I think when we have our analyst meeting, we'll talk to you more about what we expect to do in the future.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then in cost cutting, you indicated that there's a potential to increase the numbers. As you laid them out right now, the numbers are pretty meaningful over the next several years, but they do mostly come from the unregulated side of the business. Could you talk a little bit more in detail maybe about what you're looking at that's incremental to this? And any opportunities more specifically on the regulated side of the business there?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first off, I wouldn't expect them to be substantial. And what I've kind of challenged the team to do is we need to continue to find efficiencies in this business that will offset any inflationary forces on our cost structure specific to the utility
componenttext: Well, first off, I wouldn't expect them to be substantial. And what I've kind of challenged the team to do is we need to continue to find efficiencies in this business that will offset any inflationary forces on our cost structure specific to the utility side of things and in an environment where we're investing in reliability improvements now pretty much across our footprint. Taking costs out of that, out of the utilities  doesn't make sense right now. So I wouldn't expect to see a lot of it come out of the utilities. We're taking any incremental -- now it doesn't mean we're not focusing on efficient spending in the utilities. But as we create efficiencies, we are recycling that back into more investment and more improved service for customers, rather than pulling it out and ultimately reducing the cost structure for the utilities.

componenttextpreview: First question for you just on the transmission guidance increase. Your CapEx has been in line basically with plan, but the earnings power from transmissions were 10% higher than you budgeted for the year. What are you ascribing that improvement to? And h
componenttext: First question for you just on the transmission guidance increase. Your CapEx has been in line basically with plan, but the earnings power from transmissions were 10% higher than you budgeted for the year. What are you ascribing that improvement to? And how should we think about capitalizing the new baseline either for '16 and beyond?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jim. The way I would look at it, Dan, is when we went into the year, we have some relatively conservative assumptions because of the uncertainty with the forward-looking rates within ATSI, not only the ROE, but potential refunding in that. So
componenttext: Yes, this is Jim. The way I would look at it, Dan, is when we went into the year, we have some relatively conservative assumptions because of the uncertainty with the forward-looking rates within ATSI, not only the ROE, but potential refunding in that. So I would say our initial estimate was somewhat conservative, and we also have a little higher rate base associated with in-servicing some of the projects sooner than we had anticipated. When I would compare, say '16 to '15, clearly, we'll give you more guidance in our analyst meeting. But I would say the headwinds we're going to face next year is we're going to have a lower ROE in ATSI. So that's going to impact our earnings somewhat, and some of our transmission spend will be directed towards the former GPU companies where there is still on stated rates, and I would not look for formulaic rate recovery until beginning in 2017. So I would consider probably '15 and '16 years to be somewhat flattish, and then we will move on in '17 once we have the MAIT completed and invested towards GPU companies.

componenttext: Okay, that's fair enough. And then Jim, just looking at the 10-K on pension, I know this is kind of still bubbling out there. You guys set out about $880 million for pension funding in '16 and '17 and then $646 million in '18 and '19. Are those still realistic? Or is there a way to shift some of the timing of that money being put to work?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, those are still pretty much realistic, and those are based on requirements, Dan. It's not that we can shift -- we could fund more earlier. But you look at what your funding has to be over a 7-year period, and so you have to fund at least to that amoun
componenttext: No, those are still pretty much realistic, and those are based on requirements, Dan. It's not that we can shift -- we could fund more earlier. But you look at what your funding has to be over a 7-year period, and so you have to fund at least to that amount. I don't expect when we update that, '16 and '17 will be much different than what we disclosed in our 10-K for 2014, but we will just update some of the other years based on where the return on the assets are and where are the discount rate is. The Senate that just passed the, I guess, they call it bipartisan bill, it extended the funding or the smoothing requirements 3 additional years through 2020. So that will give some type of relief because you'll be able to use your historical discount rate during this funding period. So that will lessen, all things being equal, our funding requirements over that period of time.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015

componenttext: So to your assumptions in the 10-K, are those reflective of the pensions of smoothing? Or would that lower that?

componenttext: Yes, I think that's the whole game plan, Dan. Let's get Ohio behind us one way or the other, find out where that leaves us. headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And mentioned some intriguing stuff about the energy efficiency and lighting, and the deployment of that's been a little bit more aggressive than what you previously had thought. I am just wondering if you could elaborate a little bit on that in ter
componenttext: Okay. And mentioned some intriguing stuff about the energy efficiency and lighting, and the deployment of that's been a little bit more aggressive than what you previously had thought. I am just wondering if you could elaborate a little bit on that in terms of what sectors you're seeing that in and what customer classes?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: From our standpoint, the biggest impact has been in the residential sector. We've seen somewhat in commercial, but typically, commercial customers will move towards more energy efficient projects sooner than residential. But when you think about lighting,
componenttext: From our standpoint, the biggest impact has been in the residential sector. We've seen somewhat in commercial, but typically, commercial customers will move towards more energy efficient projects sooner than residential. But when you think about lighting, the federal energy efficiency lighting standards kick in 2015. You can't buy incandescent bulb right now. And we always expected that we would see some impact to our residential usage associated with that. It's just happening a little bit faster than we had originally planned on in our original load forecast.

componenttext: It's hard for me to talk about customer behaviors, especially this early on. But my suspicion is that the cost of these bulbs are coming down, and they're being offered in a number of stores. And consumers aren't just switching those bulbs sooner than we thought they would be. As we said, we're looking at this pretty closely right now, and we should have a better view on that when we come to the analyst meeting. But as we said, we ultimately knew this was going to happen. It's just maybe happening a little sooner than we expected.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the way the process work in Pennsylvania is you file a long-term infrastructure improvement plan, which pretty much details the types of investments and the impact for customers that you expect to achieve. The Pennsylvania Public Utilities Commissio
componenttext: Well, the way the process work in Pennsylvania is you file a long-term infrastructure improvement plan, which pretty much details the types of investments and the impact for customers that you expect to achieve. The Pennsylvania Public Utilities Commission reviews the LTIP. Once they review and approve the plan, then recovery under the distribution system cost recovery rider is essentially, it's a legislated recovery and it's essentially very certain after that, so as long as we spend what we're going to spend and to what we say we're going to do.

componenttext: Yes, our expectation is, well, first, bonus depreciation, we think it's likely to be extended '15 and '16 time frame. If the bonus depreciation is not extended, then we'll likely expire our NOLs around the end of 2018 or into 2019. Assuming bonus depreciation is extended that we can go out further into the 2020 time frame, again that would be impacted by the resolution of the Ohio ESP.

componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the FirstEnergy Corp. Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Meghan Beringer, Director, Investor Relations for FirstEnergy Corp. Thank you, Ms. Beringer. You may begin.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rob. Good morning, and welcome to our third quarter earnings call.  Today, we will make various forward-looking statements regarding revenues, earnings, performance, strategies and prospects. These statements are based on current expectations, and
componenttext:
Thanks, Rob. Good morning, and welcome to our third quarter earnings call.  Today, we will make various forward-looking statements regarding revenues, earnings, performance, strategies and prospects. These statements are based on current expectations, and are subject to certain risks and uncertainties. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those indicated by such statements can be found on the Investors section of our website under the Earnings Information Link and in our SEC filings, we will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations between GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures are also available on our website.  
Participating in today's call are: Chuck Jones, President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Pearson, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Donny Schneider, President of FirstEnergy Solutions; Jon Taylor, Vice President, Controller and Chief Accounting Officer; Steve Staub, Vice President and Treasurer; and Irene Prezelj, Vice President, Investor Relations.
Now I will turn the call over to Chuck Jones.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Meghan. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today.  We are pleased to report another solid quarter for FirstEnergy. Last night, we reported third quarter operating earnings of $0.98 per share, which is $0.06 above the top of our guida
componenttext:
Thanks, Meghan. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us today.  We are pleased to report another solid quarter for FirstEnergy. Last night, we reported third quarter operating earnings of $0.98 per share, which is $0.06 above the top of our guidance range for the quarter. As Jim will discuss in greater detail, these results reflect a solid performance across all 3 of our business segments. Based on our strong third quarter and year-to-date performance, we are raising and narrowing our full year 2015 operating earnings guidance to a range of $2.67 to $2.75 per share from our previous range of $2.40 to $2.70 per share. 
This is shaping up to be a great year for FirstEnergy, and as we look forward to 2016, our employees can be proud of what they have achieved. In addition to strong earnings, we have made tremendous progress on key initiatives that can provide us with greater strength and flexibility as we work to achieve our future goals. So far this year, we have clarity on the results from 2 of these initiatives: the Cash Flow Improvement Project and PJM capacity market reforms. And we continue to make progress on the third initiative, the Ohio ESP.
As we discussed in July, our Cash Flow Improvement Project exceeded our initial target, and should generate at least $240 million in cash flow improvements by 2017. That project, which solicit cost savings ideas from across the company, is rolling out as we expected. And we remain fully on track to capture the $58 million in cash flow improvements identified for 2015.  Overall, this effort is not only establishing a new cost structure for the company. It has also helped us initiate a culture change around spending. Employees continue to provide suggestions for meaningful and sustainable ways to reduce our cost structure, which could drive modest incremental savings going forward on top of what we have already communicated.
We are also cautiously optimistic about capacity market reforms that are now in place at PJM. Results from the base residual and transitional auctions held in August and September were in line with our expectations, with a pay-for-performance model resulting in clearing prices that come closer to reflecting the two -- true operating costs of our generating plants. You will recall that we raised our 2016 adjusted EBITDA guidance range for our competitive business in September as a result of the higher capacity prices and all of our uncommitted generation clearing to transitional auction for the 2016, 2017 delivery years, and we are reaffirming that range. We're also raising and narrowing our 2015 adjusted EBITDA guidance based on our year-to-date results and the impact of our cash flow initiative.
While Jim will provide more of the details about adjusted EBITDA for our competitive business in a few minutes, I wanted to take a moment to address our current thinking about 2017. All of our uncommitted generation cleared the 2017, 2018 transitional auction as well. But as you know, our proposed purchase power agreement in Ohio would impact generation sales for 7 months in 2016 and the full year of 2017. So while we considered providing an adjusted EBITDA range for 2017 on this call, we ultimately decided that we do not have enough information yet to offer a constructive view.  We remain committed to being transparent, and we intend to provide you with this outlook once there is more clarity.
With that said, we are pleased that the combination of our cash flow initiative and PJM capacity revenues from recent auctions will further strengthen the overall cash flow position for our competitive business. And you will recall that we already expected that business to be cash flow positive through at least 2018, prior to the incremental benefits of these 2 initiatives.
Many of you have asked if we intend to shut down additional plants. I tell our employees we are working hard to ensure all remaining generation remains viable. The results of the Ohio ESP and future auctions will give us a better understanding of the longer-term outlook on our at risk baseload power plants, and we continue to consider fuel and transportation contracts, as well as environmental matters such as the EPA's Clean Power Plan, which was finalized in August. We are particularly interested in hat rule's treatment of existing nuclear generation state specific emission reduction targets to compliance time line and state flexibility. While we are advocating for an interpretation that allows for a thoughtful engineering-based approach to ensure reliable energy resources for our customers, we will not have full clarity on the rule's impact until state implementation plans are submitted, which could be as late as 2018, and then approved by the EPA.
To ensure that our critical baseload power plants continue operating and to help safeguard our customers against price increases and volatility, we remain committed to our Ohio electric security plan. The evidentiary hearing for the ESP began on August 31, and rebuttal testimony was filed last week. We currently expect a decision by early 2016, and we continue our discussions with the PUCO staff and other parties to reach a positive outcome for Ohio customers.
In fact, you may have noticed that Leila is not on the call today. She is in Columbus working with the ESP, as we speak, and I think that's where we'd all rather have her. Once we have an outcome in Ohio, we have the information necessary to more fully assess FirstEnergy's earnings for 2016, regulated growth in future years, as well as our cash flow over the next several years. As we have talked about previously, at that point, we will determine future equity needs, if any, to help support our regulated growth initiatives.
We are also laying the groundwork for sustainable reliability investments in Pennsylvania. Last week, our 4 utilities in the state filed long-term infrastructure improvement plans with the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission. In total, these plans call for a projected increase in capital investment of nearly $245 million over the next 5 years to strengthen, upgrade and modernize our distribution systems. We're anticipating the PUC's approval of the LTIP proposals by mid-February. Once we have approval of the plan, we will use the distribution system improvement charge at each company to recover the appropriate fixed costs that are part of the plans.
In New Jersey, we are further enhancing our current service reliability program, with an additional $25 million spending in 2015. These expenditures, which are expected to have a $0.04 per share impact on fourth quarter 2015 earnings will not only enhance our current service reliability program, but also demonstrate our commitment to make JCP&L a stronger company. Of course, significant part of our growth plan includes our Energizing the Future transmission initiative, which remains on pace to invest $970 million this year with about 80% of that amount spent year-to-date. Recent projects include final planning and preliminary site work for a new substation near Smithfield, West Virginia, that will support the shale gas industry and enhance service reliability in Mon Power. We're also nearing completion on a transmission reinforcement project including a substation in 6-mile 138 kV line in Harrison County, West Virginia that will enhance service reliability for more than 14,000 Mon Power customers in Harrison, Lewis and Gilmore counties. We expect the substation to be energized in December.
We are pleased to report that late yesterday afternoon, FERC approved our settlement agreement for ATSI's forward-looking formula rate structure. In addition, our proposal to move our Met-Ed, Penelec and JCP&L transmission assets into a new affiliate called Mid-Atlantic Interstate Transmission or MAIT, is moving through the FERC and state approval processes. We continue to seek final state approval for MAIT by mid-2016. If approved, we expect this structure to facilitate investments that can improve service reliability for these utility customers. Lastly, we remain committed to holding an Analyst Meeting after we have results from our Ohio case.  
Now I'll turn the call over to Jim for a brief review of the quarter and our expectation for the remainder of the year. As always, we will reserve plenty of time for your questions before the end of the hour.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. Before I get started, I will remind you that more detailed information about the quarter can be found in the consolidated report that was posted to our website yesterday evening. We also welcome your questions in
componenttext:
Thanks, Chuck, and good morning, everyone. Before I get started, I will remind you that more detailed information about the quarter can be found in the consolidated report that was posted to our website yesterday evening. We also welcome your questions in the Q&A or following the call.
Our strong third quarter operating earnings of $0.98 per share compares to $0.89 per share in the third quarter of 2014. On a GAAP basis, earnings were $0.94 per share for the third quarter of 2015 compared to $0.79 per share during the same period last year. Our operating earnings primarily reflect higher distribution sales and the net impact of previously resolved rate cases, higher transmission revenues that resulted from our Energizing the Future initiative and ATSI's forward-looking rate structure and higher commodity margin in our competitive business, partially offset by higher operating expenses and a higher effective tax rate.
In our distribution business, residential sales increased 9%, and commercial sales increased 2.6% compared to the third quarter of 2014, primarily resulting from cooling degree days that were 36% higher than last year and 13% above normal.  Adjusting for weather, however, residential deliveries decreased nearly 1% and commercial sales were down 2.4%, reflecting the impact in energy efficiency mandates. As we mentioned during our second quarter call, we are examining the usage trend in all 3 customer classes, particularly the impact of energy efficiency on residential usage. And we will be prepared to discuss our load forecast in more detail during our Analyst Meeting. However, we do believe we are seeing the effects of energy-efficient lighting sooner, and with a larger impact than previous estimates.
In the industrial sector, sales decreased 3.2% in the quarter as a result of lower usage from our steel, coal mining and electrical equipment and manufacturing customers, partially offset by increased usage from the shale gas and automotive sectors. In our transmission business, third quarter operating earnings increased $0.04 to $0.17 per share as a result of higher revenue associated with a higher rate base and ATSI's forward-looking rate structure, which began in January.
In our competitive business, operating earnings increased $0.09 per share compared to the third quarter of 2014. Commodity margin increased $0.15 per share due to favorable summer weather that was warm, but not extreme, coupled with lower commodity cost. Contract sales volume decreased in line with our expectation, while wholesale sales volume increased slightly. 
Variable margin benefited from higher capacity revenues, lower purchased power costs and fuel expense and lower transmission charges. Operating costs increased compared with the third quarter of 2014, primarily due to greater expenses related to a nuclear refueling outage this quarter at Beaver Valley 2.
We remain committed to our ongoing strategy of mitigating risks by reducing sales to weather-sensitive channels, and have reduced the size of our residential retail book by approximately 38% since the third quarter of 2014 and also reduced the size of our weather-sensitive commercial and industrial book over the same period. Looking at our sales position, for 2016, we have about 59 million megawatt-hours or about 75% of our expected generation resources committed, and we are currently about 45% committed for 2017, with about 36 million megawatt-hours sold.
As Chuck discussed earlier, we are raising and narrowing our 2015 adjusted EBITDA range for the competitive business to $945 million to $975 million from $875 million to $950 million, based on our results for the first 9 months of the year and the projected savings from the Cash Flow Improvement Project. We are also reaffirming the 2016 adjusted EBITDA range that we provided in September of $950 million to $1,050,000,000. And as Chuck mentioned, we intend to provide 2017 adjusted EBITDA after the Ohio ESP is resolved.
Moving to other financial matters. During the September investor conferences, we received questions about our pension funding plan, so we wanted to spend a moment clarifying this topic. As we do each year, we disclosed our estimated pension funding requirements for the next several years as of December 31, 2014 in the Form 10-K that was filed in February. And as always, we include those future funding estimates in our internal long-term planning process. You'll recall that we contributed $143 million to our pension fund earlier this year. Consistent with our normal process we will provide an update to our estimated funding requirements for future years when we file our 2015 Form 10-K this coming February.  
I will also note that we have essentially completed our financing plans for 2015, and our expected financing plans for 2016 do not include any issuance of long-term debt until the middle of next year. As Chuck said earlier, 2015 is shaping up to be a strong and important year for FirstEnergy, as we create a new framework for our future. We have raised our operating earnings guidance based on the success of our strategies, and we are making solid progress towards our goals of building long-term value for shareholders through predictable customer-focused regulated growth.
Now I'd like to open the call for your questions.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Our first question is from Anthony Crowdell with Jefferies.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question, I guess, on Ohio PPA. I'm sure it will be a trend for the call. But just to -- I believe the record closes today in Columbus. Does the closing of the record complicate the chances of a settlement since nothing new could be introduce
componenttext: Just a quick question, I guess, on Ohio PPA. I'm sure it will be a trend for the call. But just to -- I believe the record closes today in Columbus. Does the closing of the record complicate the chances of a settlement since nothing new could be introduced?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think it complicates the opportunity for a settlement at all. I think we have the opportunity to settle the case all the way through any final outcome, actually. So it closes the record as far as anything new been introduced into the record as far
componenttext: I don't think it complicates the opportunity for a settlement at all. I think we have the opportunity to settle the case all the way through any final outcome, actually. So it closes the record as far as anything new been introduced into the record as far as testimony and remote testimony, but it doesn't prohibit ongoing discussions.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Gregg Orrill with Barclays Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Gregg Orrill with Barclays Bank.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe a follow-up there on generally how you're feeling about the process of negotiating the PPAs, and whether you feel you have better likelihood of nuclear versus coal.
componenttext: Maybe a follow-up there on generally how you're feeling about the process of negotiating the PPAs, and whether you feel you have better likelihood of nuclear versus coal.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as I've said all along, I think that the plan that we filed is the best plan for the customers in Ohio, and we continue to work to educate the commission staff as best we can on why we believe that is the case. I think we're continuing to discuss ce
componenttext: Well, as I've said all along, I think that the plan that we filed is the best plan for the customers in Ohio, and we continue to work to educate the commission staff as best we can on why we believe that is the case. I think we're continuing to discuss certain parameters around the filing. But I would expect that as we go forward, we're going to continue to talk about the PPA in somewhat the fashion that we filed it. Now having said that, there's always some room for negotiation, but I think the whole idea here is we filed a plan that's good for customers, protects them over the long haul. And at the end of the day, I've told -- I've gone through the example of what happens when a plant -- plants close in the past. It creates spending in transmission that customers pay for. So I think this plan kind of is neutral to what the transmission spending would be, and I still think it's something that we can get to across the goal line with.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just a question around the pension mark-to-market and kind of your treatment there and -- that doesn't show up in the earnings guidance, how you're thinking about that?
componenttext: And then maybe just a question around the pension mark-to-market and kind of your treatment there and -- that doesn't show up in the earnings guidance, how you're thinking about that?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greg, this is Jim. Yes, it will not show up in our operating earnings guidance. We have historically treated that as a mark-to-market. In fact, if you look at our consolidated report, we put a disclosure in there of what the range of potential impact to o
componenttext: Greg, this is Jim. Yes, it will not show up in our operating earnings guidance. We have historically treated that as a mark-to-market. In fact, if you look at our consolidated report, we put a disclosure in there of what the range of potential impact to our GAAP earnings would be if we were to mark that pension plan, effective September 30. Effective September 30, our plan had a loss on our return on assets of about 3.5% and the discount range was 4.25%. So we put a range in there, assuming that our assets' return will remain at that level and the discount rate would be anywhere between 4.25% and 4.5%. As you know, October's been a very good month in the equity markets. In fact, it's probably one of the strongest months in history. So the return on our assets has improved somewhat, and if we had to mark that today, our discount range would be in the 4.5% range. So my expectation, all things being equal, if they don't change from today, that range that we gave of $0.30 to $0.67, it would be at the lower end. In fact, it may be less than $0.37 and maybe less than $250 million that we disclosed. From a funding standpoint, we've disclosed in the 10-K last year that it would be about $1,700,000,000 for the period '15 through '19. We did contribute $143 million this year. From a funding standpoint, we'll have to see where the discount rate is and where the return on assets are at the end of the year, but I don't expect anything to be materially different than what we disclosed in our 10-K in 2014.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would just follow on a little bit to Jim's answer there. I think we've been very open in disclosing what our pension funding obligations might be and the impact on our GAAP earnings. But from the very beginning of me coming into this position, one of th
componenttext: I would just follow on a little bit to Jim's answer there. I think we've been very open in disclosing what our pension funding obligations might be and the impact on our GAAP earnings. But from the very beginning of me coming into this position, one of the things we talked about was earnings quality. And I think this quarter, $0.94 and $0.98 GAAP versus non-GAAP, we have really reduced that gap between GAAP and non-GAAP, as I told you I would. And I think our earnings quality for all 3 quarters is substantially improved, and that's the way we expect to operate going forward.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Paul Zimbardo with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from Paul Zimbardo with UBS.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Another Ohio question, if you will. We've seen a few data points on potential new builds in Ohio recently, and I was just hoping you could comment on how, if at all, you see these developments impacting the discussion with the Ohio commission staff regard
componenttext: Another Ohio question, if you will. We've seen a few data points on potential new builds in Ohio recently, and I was just hoping you could comment on how, if at all, you see these developments impacting the discussion with the Ohio commission staff regarding [indiscernible]?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't expect that they should have an impact on the discussions we're having with Ohio. And as conversely, I don't think the discussions we're having with Ohio should have any impact on any decisions for new build because the construct of our energy
componenttext: I wouldn't expect that they should have an impact on the discussions we're having with Ohio. And as conversely, I don't think the discussions we're having with Ohio should have any impact on any decisions for new build because the construct of our energy security plan, it has no impact on the competitive markets. So I don't think the 2 are linked at all.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great, and then unrelated question. I noticed the revolver borrowing declined about $1 billion quarter-over-quarter. Could you comment if this represents kind of change in now you see the financial structure?
componenttext: Okay, great, and then unrelated question. I noticed the revolver borrowing declined about $1 billion quarter-over-quarter. Could you comment if this represents kind of change in now you see the financial structure?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not sure that the revolver borrowings increased $1 billion quarter-over-quarter. In fact, if you look at our entire financing plan for the entire year, we expect to increase that by just about $350 million year-over-year, and most of that will be
componenttext: Yes, I'm not sure that the revolver borrowings increased $1 billion quarter-over-quarter. In fact, if you look at our entire financing plan for the entire year, we expect to increase that by just about $350 million year-over-year, and most of that will be new long-term debt associated with the distribution and transmission business. In fact, our revolver borrowings at the end of 2014 were about $1.8 billion, and my expectation is that they are going to be right in that range, maybe slightly less than that by the end of the year. So there's no real impact on our financing plans there.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I just looked at the short-term borrowing declined $1 billion. I know you mentioned in the past you're trying to -- or consider terming [indiscernible]?
componenttext: Okay. I just looked at the short-term borrowing declined $1 billion. I know you mentioned in the past you're trying to -- or consider terming [indiscernible]?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015

componenttext: [indiscernible] I thought you said that they were up, and that was what was confusing me. Right, no, they would be down.

componenttext: Okay. [indiscernible] is that indication that you're trying to term more out or that's just kind of normal fluctuation quarter to quarter?

componenttext: That's normal fluctuation. It's not that we're terming any of that out.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mr. Chris Turnure with JPMorgan.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to get a little bit more clarity on transmission CapEx going forward, basically versus the current CapEx that you have laid out in your slides. If you are successful with the, I guess, the innovation of the assets in New Jersey and Pennsylvania,
componenttext: I wanted to get a little bit more clarity on transmission CapEx going forward, basically versus the current CapEx that you have laid out in your slides. If you are successful with the, I guess, the innovation of the assets in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, how can we think about directional potential changes there and magnitude?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, you're going to have to wait for the Analyst Meeting. We've talked about $4.2 billion of transmission spend, a 4-year period from '14 through '17. And at this point in time, I'm not prepared to say what we expect that number to be '18 and beyond. Bu
componenttext: Well, you're going to have to wait for the Analyst Meeting. We've talked about $4.2 billion of transmission spend, a 4-year period from '14 through '17. And at this point in time, I'm not prepared to say what we expect that number to be '18 and beyond. But I think as we get through the Ohio ESP, and then we see the company that we have a base to build upon after that, I think when we have our Analyst Meeting, we'll talk to you more about what we expect to do in the future.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on cost cutting, you indicated that there's a potential to increase the numbers. As you laid them out right now, the numbers are pretty meaningful over the next several years, but they do mostly come from the unregulated side of the busines
componenttext: Okay. And then on cost cutting, you indicated that there's a potential to increase the numbers. As you laid them out right now, the numbers are pretty meaningful over the next several years, but they do mostly come from the unregulated side of the business. Could you talk a little bit more in detail maybe about what you're looking at that's incremental to this, and any opportunities more specifically on the regulated side of the business there?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first off, I wouldn't expect them to be substantial. And what I've kind of challenged the team to do is we need to continue to find efficiencies in this business that will offset any inflationary forces on our cost structure specific to the utility
componenttext: Well, first off, I wouldn't expect them to be substantial. And what I've kind of challenged the team to do is we need to continue to find efficiencies in this business that will offset any inflationary forces on our cost structure specific to the utility side of things and in an environment where we're investing in reliability improvements now pretty much across our footprint. Taking costs out of that, out of the utilities  doesn't make sense right now. So I wouldn't expect to see a lot of it come out of the utilities. We're taking any incremental -- now it doesn't mean we're not focusing on efficient spending in the utilities. But as we create efficiencies, we're recycling that back into more investment and more improved service for customers, rather than pulling it out and ultimately reducing the cost structure for the utilities.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Mr. Dan Eggers with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from Mr. Dan Eggers with Credit Suisse.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question for you just on the transmission guidance increase. Your CapEx has been in line basically with plan, but the earnings power from transmissions were 10% higher than you've budgeted for the year. What are you ascribing that improvement to, an
componenttext: First question for you just on the transmission guidance increase. Your CapEx has been in line basically with plan, but the earnings power from transmissions were 10% higher than you've budgeted for the year. What are you ascribing that improvement to, and how should we think about capitalizing the new baseline either for '16 and beyond?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Jim. The way I would look at that Dan, is that when we went into the year, we had some relatively conservative assumptions because of the uncertainty with the forward-looking rates within ATSI, not only the ROE, but potential refunding in tha
componenttext: Yes, this is Jim. The way I would look at that Dan, is that when we went into the year, we had some relatively conservative assumptions because of the uncertainty with the forward-looking rates within ATSI, not only the ROE, but potential refunding in that. So I would say our initial estimate was somewhat conservative, and we also have a little higher rate base associated with in-servicing some of the projects sooner than we had anticipated. When I would compare, say '16 to '15, clearly, we'll give you more guidance at our Analyst Meeting. But I would say the headwinds we're going to face next year is we're going to have a lower ROE in ATSI. So that's going to impact our earnings somewhat, and some of our transmission spend will be directed towards the former GPU companies, where there's unstated d rates, and I would not look for formulaic rate recovery until beginning in 2017. So I would consider probably '15 and '16 years to be somewhat flattish, and then we will move on in '17 once we have the MAIT completed and investments going towards the GPU companies.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That was helpful. On the demand response case, Supreme Court's heard it now. Obviously, you guys are very vested in the process. What was your read on what happened in the Supreme Court, and then your expectations for when we'll get a decision and then wh
componenttext: That was helpful. On the demand response case, Supreme Court's heard it now. Obviously, you guys are very vested in the process. What was your read on what happened in the Supreme Court, and then your expectations for when we'll get a decision and then whatever adoptions that the PJM will have to make?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I should have preempted all of the Q&A by stating as I said earlier, Leila is not here, and I don't think you want any of us, other than Leila, judging what's happening at the Supreme Court. So here's what I'll do, Dan. Irene will talk with Leila, and
componenttext: So I should have preempted all of the Q&A by stating as I said earlier, Leila is not here, and I don't think you want any of us, other than Leila, judging what's happening at the Supreme Court. So here's what I'll do, Dan. Irene will talk with Leila, and we'll get back to you on that one, but I just don't feel comfortable asking -- answering technical legal questions.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's fair enough. And then Jim, just looking back at the 10-K on pension, I know this is kind of still bubbling out there. You guys had set out about $880 million for pension funding in '16 and '17 and then $646 million in '18, '19. Are those stil
componenttext: Okay, that's fair enough. And then Jim, just looking back at the 10-K on pension, I know this is kind of still bubbling out there. You guys had set out about $880 million for pension funding in '16 and '17 and then $646 million in '18, '19. Are those still realistic or is there a way to shift some of the timing of that money being put to work?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, those are still pretty much realistic, and those are based on requirements, Dan. It's not that we can shift -- we could fund more earlier. But you look at what your funding has to be over a 7-year period, and so you have to fund at least that amount.
componenttext: No, those are still pretty much realistic, and those are based on requirements, Dan. It's not that we can shift -- we could fund more earlier. But you look at what your funding has to be over a 7-year period, and so you have to fund at least that amount. I don't expect when we update that, '16 and '17 will be much different than what we disclosed in our 10-K for 2014, but we will just update some of the outer years based on where the return on the assets are and where the discount rate is. The Senate that just passed the, I guess, they call it the bipartisan budget bill, it extended the funding or the smoothing requirements, 3 additional years through 2020. So that will give some type of relief because you'll be able to use your historical discount rate during those funding period. So that will lessen, all things being equal, our funding requirements over that period of time.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So to your assumptions in the 10-K, are those reflective of the extension of the smoothing or would that lower that number?
componenttext: So to your assumptions in the 10-K, are those reflective of the extension of the smoothing or would that lower that number?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. The 10-K that we filed in 2014 did not take into account any of the changes to the, smoothing. And primarily, that smoothing doesn't impact your funding until year 2019.
componenttext: No. The 10-K that we filed in 2014 did not take into account any of the changes to the, smoothing. And primarily, that smoothing doesn't impact your funding until year 2019.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then I guess just on the financing side of it, and you guys have been keen not to talk about equity needs and that sort of thing, but should we expect more comprehensive planning update at the Analyst Day? And would that then include whatever you'd have to help to fund for the pension perspective?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's the whole game plan, Dan, is let's get Ohio behind us one way or the other, find out where that leaves us. We know pretty much where capacity performance landed, and we know what we've done internally to strengthen our cash flows. I th
componenttext: Yes, I think that's the whole game plan, Dan, is let's get Ohio behind us one way or the other, find out where that leaves us. We know pretty much where capacity performance landed, and we know what we've done internally to strengthen our cash flows. I think at that point in time, we're going to give you more review towards the future. 2015 has been all about kind of strengthening the base that we want to build from.

componenttext: I would say that probably about 60% of the unfunded would reside in the regulated-like companies.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you mentioned some intriguing stuff about the energy efficiency and lighting, and now the deployment of that's been a little bit more aggressive than what you previously have thought. I'm just wondering if you could elaborate a little bit o
componenttext: Okay. And then you mentioned some intriguing stuff about the energy efficiency and lighting, and now the deployment of that's been a little bit more aggressive than what you previously have thought. I'm just wondering if you could elaborate a little bit on that in terms of what sectors you're seeing that in and what customer classes?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. From our standpoint, the biggest impact has been in the residential sector. We've seen somewhat in commercial. Typically, commercial customers will move towards more energy efficient projects sooner than residential. But when you think about the ligh
componenttext: Yes. From our standpoint, the biggest impact has been in the residential sector. We've seen somewhat in commercial. Typically, commercial customers will move towards more energy efficient projects sooner than residential. But when you think about the lighting, the federal energy efficient lighting standards kicked in 2015, you can't buy an incandescent bulb right now. And we always expected that we would see some impact to our residential usage associated with that. It's just happening a little bit faster than we had originally planned on, on our original load forecast.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: How much of that -- I mean, I guess, why is that, do you think, and because like you said, all of the stuff is sort of known. I mean, what do you -- could you give us a little bit more of a flavor as to how much more of this you're seeing, and why you thi
componenttext: How much of that -- I mean, I guess, why is that, do you think, and because like you said, all of the stuff is sort of known. I mean, what do you -- could you give us a little bit more of a flavor as to how much more of this you're seeing, and why you think you're seeing it?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's hard for me to talk about customer behaviors, especially this early on, but my suspicion is that the cost of these bulbs are coming down, and they're being offered in a number of stores, and consumers are just switching those bulbs sooner than we tho
componenttext: It's hard for me to talk about customer behaviors, especially this early on, but my suspicion is that the cost of these bulbs are coming down, and they're being offered in a number of stores, and consumers are just switching those bulbs sooner than we thought they would be. And as we said, we're looking at this pretty closely right now, and we should have a better view on that when we come to the Analyst Meeting. But as we said, we ultimately knew this was going to happen. It's just maybe happening a little sooner than we expected.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And we'll find out obviously in the Analyst Meeting what it means for energy -- for the energy efficiency . That would suggest that you guys are expecting to see more sooner than previously thought. Is that how it is going?
componenttext: Okay. And we'll find out obviously in the Analyst Meeting what it means for energy -- for the energy efficiency . That would suggest that you guys are expecting to see more sooner than previously thought. Is that how it is going?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015

componenttext: Yes, we'll have that built into the load forecast that we have, yes.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just had one last. The LTIP that was filed in Pennsylvania a couple weeks ago, it implies from the release, that's a quarterly rate rider. Is that a done deal? I mean, is that legislation or is that Commission President or another utility that spun that
componenttext: I just had one last. The LTIP that was filed in Pennsylvania a couple weeks ago, it implies from the release, that's a quarterly rate rider. Is that a done deal? I mean, is that legislation or is that Commission President or another utility that spun that? So you're pretty confident you'll get that quarterly rider?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the way the process works in Pennsylvania is you file a long-term infrastructure improvement plan, which pretty much details the types of investments and the impact for customers that you expect to achieve. The Pennsylvania Public Utilities Commissi
componenttext: Well, the way the process works in Pennsylvania is you file a long-term infrastructure improvement plan, which pretty much details the types of investments and the impact for customers that you expect to achieve. The Pennsylvania Public Utilities Commission reviews the LTIP. Once they review and approve the plan, then recovery under the distribution system cost recovery rider is essentially -- it's a legislated recovery and it's essentially very certain after that. So as long as we spend what we say we're going to spend and do what we say we're going to do.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ashar Khan with Visium.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ashar Khan with Visium.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Chuck, just going back to the expectations of getting this case done by early next year, is it fair to assume that if we are able to reach a settlement, it should come in the next month or so?
componenttext: Chuck, just going back to the expectations of getting this case done by early next year, is it fair to assume that if we are able to reach a settlement, it should come in the next month or so?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to handicap it Ashar. I mean, we're working every day, talking on the phone. Leila is down there meeting with the staff today, working through a lot of complex issues, and it's a very complex case. So I don't want to put pressure on Leila no
componenttext: I'm not going to handicap it Ashar. I mean, we're working every day, talking on the phone. Leila is down there meeting with the staff today, working through a lot of complex issues, and it's a very complex case. So I don't want to put pressure on Leila nor on the commission staff or any other parties that we're talking with. We just keep working through the process. And I believe that there's an opportunity for an ultimate settlement because I think that we're getting to the point where everybody's starting to really understand why it's good for customers.

componenttext: What Donny is describing is we're going to run that business kind of like a utility. We're going to sell forward 2/3 to 3/4 of our available generation. componenttext: Yes, our expectation is that, well, first, bonus depreciation, we think it's likely to be extended through the '15 and '16 time frame. That's not part of the budget bill, but it's typically done usually at the end of the year in an extender. If the bonus depreciation is not extended, then will likely expire our NOLs around the end of 2018 or into 2019. Assuming bonus depreciation is extended, then we could go out further into the 2020 time frame. Again, that would be impacted by the resolution of the Ohio ESP.

componenttext:
Well, I would say that I think we're all just kind of trying to speculate about what could happen. We're being a little more conservative maybe than AEP, and that traditionally, there's not going to get a lot done in December after Thanksgiving for our case to get settled by the end of this calendar year. They have to work pretty hard pretty much the whole month of December, I think, to meet the time tables, so we're just expecting it will likely get done after the first of the year.
Okay. Well, I don't see any more questions on our call, so I want to thank you all very much for your support, and I'll just say I look forward to seeing you a week from Monday at EEI, and I'm sure we'll go through all the same questions again. Thank you.
